question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The General Budget Directorate (DIGEPRES) is the responsible agency in this area (1). The legal framework of this directorate is govern by multiple laws. The Law No. 101-79 indicates that the directorate has to submit  monthly reports income and expenses of the government in Article 1-3 (2).

The Organic Budget for the Public Sector Law (Law No. 423-06), in Article 11 establish the principle of transparency and publication (3). It implies the guarantee of periodic public communication and free access to information by the citizenship on budget management.

Source

(1) DIGEPRES Website. https://www.digepres.gob.do/
(2) Law No. 101-79 on the obligation to submit monthly reports Income and Expenses. https://www.digepres.gob.do/transparencia/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/2.8.1.1.5-LEY-101-79-SOBRE-OBLIGATORIEDAD-DE-PRESENTAR-REPORTES-MENSUALES-INGRESOS-Y-EGRESOS.pdf
(3) Law No. 423-06 The Organic Budget for the Public Sector Law. https://www.digepres.gob.do/transparencia/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Ley-Num-423-06-de-2006.pdf

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
DIGEPRES is the institution in charge of publishing the datasets, they don't specify the license on which the datasets are published. The datasets have different time range, the largest cover a 50 year period. The data is updated to April 2021.

The budget data is structured and separated into multiple datase. On their website they publish the government income (2), expenditure (3), balance (4), consolidate (5) and budget execution (6).

Source

(1) DIGEPRES Website. https://www.digepres.gob.do/

(3) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas/gastos/

(5) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas/consolidado/
(6) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas-ejecucion-presupuestaria/

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Financial and Administration and Audit Act and Amendments guide the publication of financial data (1) and (2). Annual budget reports are published on the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service, including information about public debt (3). A Chief Internal Auditor by law is appointed to verify all budget estimates.

Sources
(1) https://moj.gov.jm/sites/default/files/laws/The%20Financial%20Administration%20and%20Audit%20Act_0.pdf
(2) https://moj.gov.jm/sites/default/files/laws/The%20Financial%20Administration%20and%20Audit%20Act.pdf
(3) https://mof.gov.jm/documents/documents-publications/document-centre/category/193-public-debt-annual-reports.html

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The budget is the law which guides yearly spending in Trinidad and Tobago (1). There is a constitutional mandate under section 113-1 of the Constitution (2,) which states that the budget must be presented before or no later than 30 days after the commencement of each financial year, estimates of revenue and expenditure for that year. Circular calls help with the establishment of the budget (3)through the collection of information from various ministries. The implementation of the budget is guided by the EXCHEQUER AND AUDIT ACT CHAPTER 69:01 (4.). However, none of these laws surveyed dealt with publication of data. The Open Budget Survey Report (5) showed the Trinidad and Tobago ranked 90th of 117 countries its last assessment.

Sources:
(1) GoRTT Budget Statement 2021.  https://www.finance.gov.tt/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Budget-Statement-2021-1.pdf
(2)  Trinidad and Tobago Act No. 4 of 1976.  http://laws.gov.tt/pdf/Act1976_4.pdf
(3)Call Circular 02, dated March 24, 2021. https://www.finance.gov.tt/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Minister-of-Finance-Call-Circular-No.-2-dated-March-24-2021.pdf
(4)The Exchequer and Audit Act, Chapter 69:01.  https://www.finance.gov.tt/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/The-Exchequer-and-Audit-Act.pdf
(5)Open Budget Survey Report.  https://stories.tteiti.com/budget-guide/index.html

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
A comprehensive set of Trinidad and Tobago Governmental budgetary information are readily available online for various year,  September 14 2001 - October 5, 2020. Included in these budgetary reports are 2021 Estimates of Expenditure (1), Statutory Boards Revenue and Expenditure (2), Recurrent Expenditure (3), Development Expenditure and 2020 Supplementary Appropriation (4) and Mid Year Review (5).  These to give a holistic picture of governmental budgetary activities as they relate to data.

1. 2021 Estimates of Expenditure. https://www.finance.gov.tt/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Estimates-of-Expenditure-for-the-Financial-Year-2021.pdf

4. Development Expenditure. https://www.finance.gov.tt/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Public-Sector-Investment-Programme.pdf

question: The framework requires a verification process.
2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response:
State Treasury accounts for the payments made to incur the expenditures under the State
Budget in line with the budget classification that covers information for every phase of the
payment. State Treasury also accounts for the revenues by the budget classification and
refund of excess tax revenues. The State Treasury produces reports on the execution of the State Budget, covering the revenues, expenditures, balance adjustment and total net balance within 20 days from the end of every single month. Referred reports are submitted to the Parliament of Georgia. 

Additionally, the State Audit Office reviews the annual report of the Government of Georgia on State Budget Execution and submits the report to the Parliament of Georgia. 

These processes are detailed in Chapter X of the Budget Code of Georgia.

question: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g., defence sector.)
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Most of the Budget data is accessible through the website of the Ministry of Finance(1), however, it is highly aggregated. Within the framework of the OGP Georgia Action Plan 2016-2017, the State Audit Office developed an analytical platform "Budget Monitor"(2), by means of which the wide public can access information about the state budget, public resources management issues, audit findings, issued recommendations and the state of their implementation(3). While The data is quite comprehensive, it is usually updated quite a bit late than the publication of documents by the Ministry of Finance. Even though Georgia has been scoring fairly high in international rankings in areas such as budget transparency(4), challenges remain in terms of openness. There is still no way to access data in bulk, and the most common formats that are being used to publish, are not ideal for data analysis.

Sources:
(1):https://www.mof.ge/en/4545
(2):https://budgetmonitor.ge/en
(3):https://ogpgeorgia.gov.ge/upload/pages/24/OGP%20Georgia%20Action%20Plan%20for%202018-2019.pdf
(4):https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/georgia
[Budget data section on the website of the Ministry of Finance](https://www.mof.ge/en/4545)

response:
Egypt has a well structured law for the public finance and it organises all related processes of the state budget formulation. Despite that, each year, the parliament passes the proposal of the state budget based on approving a law specifically for the state budget along with the national plan. 
There are some setbacks with transparency measures and publishing data regularly, however, the situation is getting some improvements than earlier.

question: Existence

1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
Egypt has no.53 law for year 1973 that declares the public finance process and the general budget with every related issue. 
Also, each year, for the general budget to be approved, a law from the parliament has to be declared.

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The situation with public finance is good enough to be investigated and assessed in Egypt. The ministry of Finance is committed to follow international standards when it comes to transparency and publishing data sets. This commitment does not negate the fact of having some drawbacks in the way of publishing data as data is entirely published in forms of reports and there is no datasets/databases sheets or window so the user could reach the figures easily.
The structure is probably the same over the years so that creates a sense of familiarity to the user when looking for data within the budget structure.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response: The Jordanian legal framework makes the publishing of the government budget, spending and loans mandatory. Although these data are considered public, and should be published as open data according to a 2020 data classification policy, there are no explicit regulations requiring budget information to be published as structured and disaggregated data.

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response: The Organic Budget Law no. 13 of 2021 requires the General Budget Department to publish the government budget (Article 3(f)) and government spending, debt and borrowing on a monthly basis (Article 22). The Audit Bureau Law no. 28 of 1952 stipulates that budget expenditures, spending of public institutions, and loans should be audited or monitored by the Bureau and an annual report should be made available publicly, including the possibility to be published on their website.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The article 14 of the law nÂ° 2016-1321 for a Digital Republic, October 7, 2016 is the main legal framework that established a public service of the data, hence the collection and publication of data, such as public finance (1). The law establishes the principle that the data produced or collected by the administration, as well as the source codes of its main computer applications, are henceforth to be published online.
The article 14 created the article L.321-4 in the Code of relations between the public and the administration. This article is related to the quality of data, their collection and publication, the coordination of this public service (2). This article L.321-4 is transposed in one decree of application (3) and one order of application (4) that details the legal obligations for public administrations. 
Public finance data are available on the Ministry of Economy of Finance website (5), a dedicated platform for public budget (6), on the French Internal Revenue Service website (7), and on the open data governmental portal (8). We can access the annual national budget, voted as a Finance Act every year by the Parliament (9); expenditures for each administration at the national, regional, local levels (10).

--

SOURCES: 
(1) Article 14 of the law nÂ° 2016-1321 for a Digital Republic, October 7, 2016: https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/loda/article_lc/LEGIARTI000033205148/
(2) Article L.321-4 in the Code of relations between the public and the administration: https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/codes/article_lc/LEGIARTI000033219118/
(3) Decree nÂ° 2017-331 on the public service for making reference data available, March 14, 2017 
https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/loda/id/JORFTEXT000034194946/
(4)Order of June 14, 2017 on the technical and organizational rules for making reference data available as provided for in Article L. 321-4 of the Code of Relations between the Public and the Administration: https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jorf/id/JORFTEXT000034944648
(5) Ministry of Economy of Finance website: https://www.economie.gouv.fr/cedef/chiffres-cles-budget-etat
(6) Budget Gouv Portal: https://www.budget.gouv.fr/
(7) French Internal Revenue Service: https://www.impots.gouv.fr/portail/ouverture-des-donnees-publiques-de-la-dgfip
(8) Open Data Gouv Portal: https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/deniers-publics-donnees-ouvertes-spallian/
(9) Annual Finance Act (budget) https://data.economie.gouv.fr/explore/dataset/projet-de-loi-de-finances-pour-2020-plf-2020-donnees-du-plf-et-des-annexes-proje/information/
(10) Ministry of Economy of Finance (territorial public finance) https://www.economie.gouv.fr/cedef/chiffres-cles-budgets-collectivites-locales

barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Budget execution data can be found on multiple portals. For national budget, the Budget Gouv Portal (1) and the Data Economie Gouv Portal (2) provide government budget and expenditures. At the regional and local levels, we have to visit each official website (e.g: region or city website), those data are aggregated and summarized on the Ministry of Economy of Finance (3).
Administrative classifications don't follow international standards. The data are primarily intended for the French citizens. Data is not disaggregated by cross-cutting programs but by missions and state operators. 

--
SOURCES:
(1) Budget Gouv Portal: https://www.budget.gouv.fr/
(2) Data Economie Gouv Portal: https://data.economie.gouv.fr/pages/accueil/
(3) Ministry of Economy of Finance (territorial public finance) https://www.economie.gouv.fr/cedef/chiffres-cles-budgets-collectivites-locales

question: 1,2;Please, briefly explain your answer.
response:
The State Purchasing Department (DAE) publishes the schedule of purchases that ministries will potentially have to make over the period from the end of 2020 to the end of 2023, excluding defense or security purchases.
This publication is in response to the desire to develop and improve dialogue between buyers and companies, as well as to simplify companies' access to government contracts. It should enable companies to better understand the State's potential purchasing needs, and to anticipate their participation in opportunities that interest them. 
It covers purchases potentially planned by the State Purchasing Department, the 13 regional State purchasing platforms and all ministries. It indicates the subject of the planned purchase, the estimated amount and duration of the purchase, its organizational scope.

https://data.economie.gouv.fr/explore/dataset/programmation-des-achats-de-letat-2020-2023/table/

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
There is no evidence that a legal framework specific to publishing budget data exists. However, the regulations and requirements on open data as well as the Stategy of the German government (1) apply to all federal administrations. The Budgetary Principles Act (2) also sets how the budget should be structured and data presented, even though it makes no mention of publication requirements. 
The budget data is available in machine readable format, as structured data with an open license, and downloadable online on the government portals.

SOURCES: 
(1) Datenstrategie der Bundesregierung, 2021. Link: https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/992814/1845634/45aee6da9554115398cc6a722aba08cb/datenstrategie-der-bundesregierung-download-bpa-data.pdf?download=1
(2) Budgetary Principles Act of 19 August 1969 (Federal Law Gazette I, p. 1273), last amended by Article 1 of the Act of 15 July 2013 (Federal Law Gazette I, p. 2398). Link: https://www.bundesfinanzministerium.de/Content/EN/Gesetze/Laws/1969-08-19-budgetary-principles-act.html

barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Matters related to the budget are regulated by the Budgetary Principles Act (HaushaltsgrundsÃ¤tzegesetz) (1). 

Budget data is available on several data portals, including Germany's open data portal GovData.de (2). Other sources are the website of the Ministry of finance providing an interactive platform to view budget data (3), and the data portal of the Ministry of finance (4) that is the initial provider for the GovData portal. 

The budget code defines the classification for revenue and expenditures: 
- specific type (object)
- functional area
- group 
This classification does not mention any specific international classification but it is expected that this is not an unusual classification. 

Data on specific cross-sectional items such as the SDGs or climate action fall into various categories of the budget and are not displayed on the datasets under assessment. However, this data may be available in other datasets or specific Ministry webpage. 

There is no evidence that the budget data is provided on an accrual basis.

The data assessed covers the federal budget. Individual states have their own budget and Ministries. 

SOURCES: 
(1) Budgetary Principles Act of 19 August 1969 (Federal Law Gazette I, p. 1273), last amended by Article 1 of the Act of 15 July 2013 (Federal Law Gazette I, p. 2398). Link: https://www.bundesfinanzministerium.de/Content/EN/Gesetze/Laws/1969-08-19-budgetary-principles-act.html
(2) GovData.de - Bundeshaushalt. Link: https://www.govdata.de/web/guest/suchen/-/searchresult/q/bundeshaushalt/s/relevance_desc
(3) Bundeshaulhalt.de - BMF. Link: https://www.bundeshaushalt.de/#
(4) Das Datenportal des BMF. Link: https://www.bundesfinanzministerium.de/Datenportal/start.html

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Although there is an obligation to make all public finance instruments (national and local) transparent and accessible through the Bdap and the local finance service of the Ministry of the Interior, and despite the fact that in recent years progress has been made on transparency of public administration accounts, the data are still accessible to a small circle of people, insiders. If it is possible to download them, it is not easy for the ordinary citizen to get an idea and make a comparison. Just compare the page where you can download the financial statements from the Italian interior ministry website and a similar service in Denmark.

Sources: 
(1): https://finanzalocale.interno.gov.it/apps/floc.php/certificati/index/codice_ente/3120700900/anno/2018/cod/4/md/0/tipo_modello/X
(2): https://www.dst.dk/en/Statistik/emner/nationalregnskab-og-offentlige-finanser/kommuner-og-regioner/kommunernes-budgetter
(3): https://openbdap.mef.gov.it/
(4): https://www.normattiva.it/uri-res/N2Ls?urn:nir:stato:legge:2009-12-31;196
(5): https://dait.interno.gov.it/finanza-locale
(6): http://dati.istat.it/
(7): https://temi.camera.it/leg17/temi/trasparenza_pa

question: 1,2;Please provide brief details.
response: According to a 2009 law http://www.normattiva.it/uri-res/N2Ls?urn:nir:stato:legge:2009-12-31;196 public finance must be open to scrutiny: data must be published in a database (articles 6 and 13). Local administrations must send their budgets to the Public Administration Database (Bdap), controlled by the "State Accounting Office", a department of the Ministry of Economy.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
response: Requirements to publish this information as open data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
response:
The Public finance Management Act https://en.camera.it/application/xmanager/projects/camera_eng/file/Government_Accounting_and_Public_Finance_Act_Law_31_December_2009_n_196_def.pdf establishes in article 6 2-bis that the information should be in open format 

Local authorities also send their budgets to the Ministry of the Interior, which publishes them: https://finanzalocale.interno.gov.it/apps/floc.php/certificati/index/codice_ente/3120700900/anno/2018/cod/4/md/0/model_type/X

Finally, the national statistical institute (Istat) provides a dataset with respect to this issue: http://dati.istat.it
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
National government public expenditure data is available on the public administration database (Bdap). However, the level of accessibility and disaggregation of the data itself still needs to be improved.

Sources:
(1): https://openbdap.mef.gov.it/it/
(2): https://bdap-opendata.mef.gov.it/sites/default/files/metadata_updfile/report/1928_BDAP%20-%20Anagrafe%20Ente%20-%20Metadati_0.pdf
(3): https://openbdap.mef.gov.it/data/foia_bilanci/BDAP-Bilanci%20Armonizzati%20Allegato%20tecnico%20V32.pdf
(4): https://www.agid.gov.it/index.php/it/dati/formati-aperti/xbrl-standard-formato-elettronico-editabile
(5): https://openbdap.mef.gov.it/data/foia_bilanci/CONTROLLI%20BILANCI%20ARMONIZZATI.pdf
(6): https://www.siope.it/Siope/dispatchHome.action
(7): https://opencoesione.gov.it/it/

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Portugal has been a late comer to collecting and publishing data on public finances. Still in recent years, concrete steps have been taken, such as joining the Open Government Partnership.

Law 151/2015 "Lei de Enquadramento OrÃ§amental" (1) sets the regime of the budget process, the rules of execution, accounting and budget and financial reporting, as well as the rules of inspection, control and audit. In terms of publication of data, it is made compulsory for the government to make (aggregated) budget information public. It is put rather simply, with no reference to other requirements to the data.
Also, Law 26/2016 defines rules of access to public administration information (2), and in its Art. 2 it states the Principle of Open Governance, bringing core concepts of open access, but again not dwelling into anything technical or quality-related.

(1) Law 151/2015 https://www.dgo.gov.pt/legislacao/Documents/Lei_151-2015_LEO.pdf
(2) Law 26/2016 http://www.pgdlisboa.pt/leis/lei_mostra_articulado.php?nid=2591&tabela=leis&so_miolo

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Providing government budget and spending information as open data has not been a priority for the Portuguese administration. Consequently, this information is either fragmented, or not accessible in machine readable format.
There is some very crude data available at the Portuguese Open Data Portal (1) which is dwarfed by the static PDF version of the national budget (2).
There is a promise by the government that government spending data/information will be openly accessible, but so far it has not yet be implemented.

(1) Government spending in open data format https://dados.gov.pt/pt/datasets/conta-geral-do-estado-despesa-por-classificacao-economica/
(2) National Budget 2021 https://app.parlamento.pt/webutils/docs/doc.pdf?path=6148523063446f764c324679626d56304c334e706447567a4c31684a566b786c5a79394562324e31625756756447397a5357357059326c6864476c325953396d4f4751315a6a426a5a693077597a6b304c5451304f5451744f44637a597930795a6a5a695957557a595445784e7a49755a47396a65413d3d&fich=f8d5f0cf-0c94-4494-873c-2f6bae3a1172.docx&Inline=true
(3) Newspaper article 
https://www.publico.pt/2021/09/17/economia/opiniao/orcamento-estado-nao-ministerio-financas-1977731

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The mention of summary reports being provided as structured data, were not found in the framework although Organic Law on Budgetary Stability and Financial Sustainability (1) article 17 and 24 note dates that different reports need to be made public and / or presented but it does not mention how these reports should be published, different reports can be found on the Ministry's website in PDF (2).
Again there was no mention to expenditure information being provided as structured data the Organic Law on Budgetary Stability and Financial Sustainability (1) article 27, states that the Budgets of each Public Administration shall be accompanied by the precise information to relate the balance of the income and expenses in accordance with the rules of the European System of National and Regional Accounts (3) but it does not state if there are any limitations or how the information should be presented. On the other hand, information publicly available on the State Administrations General Intervention website (4) does not break down each group of expenditures. 
Although no mention was found to how different reports should be published, thttps://www.bohe reports found on the Ministry of Finance website (5) are available in PDF. Summaries on the The Secretary of State for Budgets and Expenditures website (6) can be found in a structured form    



(1)	Organic Law on Budgetary Stability and Financial Sustainability https://www.boe.es/buscar/act.php?id=BOE-A-2012-5730 
(2)	Ministry of Finance  https://www.hacienda.gob.es/es-ES/CDI/Paginas/EstabilidadPresupuestaria/InformesCompletosLEP.aspx
(3)	European System of National and Regional Accounts https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32013R0549&from=EN
(4)	 State Administrations General Intervention https://www.igae.pap.hacienda.gob.es/sitios/igae/es-ES/Contabilidad/ContabilidadPublica/CPE/EjecucionPresupuestaria/Paginas/imavancecomentado.aspx 
(5)	Ministry of Finance https://www.hacienda.gob.es/es-ES/CDI/Paginas/EstabilidadPresupuestaria/InformesCompletosLEP.aspx 
(6)	Secretary of State for Budgets and Expenditures https://www.sepg.pap.hacienda.gob.es/Presup/PGE2021Ley/MaestroDocumentos/PGE-ROM/Series.htm
(7)	Spanish Constitution https://www.boe.es/buscar/act.php?id=BOE-A-1978-31229
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The information on the General State Budgets Project 2021 website (1) is abundant, but it is very hard to locate precise information as it has been broken down into different files: Red, Green, Yellow, Grey and Blue. Each section contains different information. The red section includes the documentation that, once approved by the "Cortes Generales", is part of the General State Budget Law, and the numerical statements of income and expenses. The green provides auxiliary and accounting development information, public investment projects (classified territorially) multi-year information, as well as the personnel and program annexes. The yellow section contains information that explains the large figures contained in the General State Budgets, among other documents, it includes the Economic and Financial Report which, together with information on the Spanish economy and its prospects, includes the main characteristics of the General State Budgets, spending policies, financing of Territorial Administrations, public investment, etc. The grey section includes information such as the previous year's budgets and the current years progress. The blue section gives a cross-sectional view of the General State Budgets and includes the Gender Impact Report, and the Report on the alignment of the General State Budgets with the Sustainable Development Goals of 2030 Agenda.
Evidence that the Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard could not be found but the Resolution of January 20, 2014, of the General Directorate of Budgets, by which the codes that define the economic classification are defined outlines the classifications (2).
 

(1)General State Budgets Project 2021 website https://www.sepg.pap.hacienda.gob.es/Presup/PGE2021Proyecto/MaestroDocumentos/PGE-ROM/Series.htm
(2) Resolution of January 20, 2014, https://www.boe.es/diario_boe/txt.php?id=BOE-A-2014-879

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Law 2016: 1091 on budget and financial administration for the government authorities (1) does not cover the budget reports to be published as open data. In article 9, section 1 Â§, the authorities are obliged to report to the government over the assets that the authority manages and disposes of. The accounting obligation also includes the authority's debts and other financial commitments. 

In the Budget Law, article 10, section 1 Â§ (2) the Government is accountable to the parliament for the assets that the Government manages and has at its disposal. There is no mention of this data to be published as open data.


(1)SFS 2016:1091 Lag om budget och ekonomiadministration fÃ¶r riksdagens myndigheter, article 9, section 1 Â§. 2016, https://www.riksdagen.se/sv/dokument-lagar/dokument/svensk-forfattningssamling/lag-20161091-om-budget-och_sfs-2016-1091

(2)SFS 2011:203 Budgetlag, article 10, section 1 Â§, 2011, https://www.riksdagen.se/sv/dokument-lagar/dokument/svensk-forfattningssamling/budgetlag-2011203_sfs-2011-203

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Public Finance Act provides for the collection and publication of this data. The entire control of the state budget, including significant parts - debts and subsidies - of the municipal budgets are under the Minister of Finance which is a guarantee for its publication. However, the data is not published in open formats by the different bodies. Some of the data is summarized and published as open data by the Ministry of Finance.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Although the Budget Act prescribes the principle of transparency in article 12 and obligations of timely publishing budget data, there are no specific requirements about the format for publicly available. (1) 
On the other hand, the Ministry of Finance collects structured data as prescribed in the Circular to prepare and submit financial statements of the budget for the year 2020. (2) Similarly, the Ordinance on the manner and conditions of execution of the state budget proclaims that records of all expenditures should enter in the state treasury system for every invoice (3). Additionally, the Ministry of Finance undertakes to open the data by implementing the Open Government Partnership Action Plans (4)
The Law on the State Audit Office prescribes the audit on the execution of the state budget. The annual audit is performed every year, and the report on the completed audit is submitted to the Croatian Parliament by 15 June of the current year for the previous year. (5) 
There is no mention of data formats or the publication of open data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.

Sources:
(1) The Budget Act, article 12, 2008/15 (consolidated text), https://mfin.gov.hr/UserDocsImages/dokumenti/proracun/Budget%20Act%20-%20consolidated%20text.pdf
(2) Ordinance on the manner and conditions of execution of the state budget and on the manner of returning funds to the state budget and keeping records on the return of funds, article 9, 2011/17,
https://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/69875/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2011_04_48_1085.html
(3) Circular on the preparation and submission of financial statements of the budget, 2020, https://mfin.gov.hr/UserDocsImages//dokumenti/drzavna-riznica/izvjestavanje/2020//Okru%C5%BEnica%20I-VI%202020.pdf
(4) Action Plan OGP till 2020, Fiscal Transparency, https://www.opengovpartnership.org/members/croatia/commitments/HR0027/
(5) The Law on the State Audit Office, article 19, paragraph 2, 2019, http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/195825/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/full/2019_03_25_490.html
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: 2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response:
The Law on the State Audit Office prescribes the audit on the execution of the state budget. The annual audit is performed every year, and the report on the completed audit is submitted to the Croatian Parliament by 15 June of the current year for the previous year. (1)
Sources:
(1) The Law on the State Audit Office, article 19, paragraph 2, 2019, http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/195825/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/full/2019_03_25_490.html

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Although the data on amended, and approved budgets are publicly available on the Ministry of Finance web page, none are structured as a dataset but mostly presented at separate tables. (1)
The budget proposal, however, is available only in pdf on the Croatian Parliament web page. (2)
On the other hand, spending data for the state budget is presented in the State Treasury application (3) and can be download in bulk (4). All state budget's data share common identifiers following the 
Ordinance on budget classifications. (5) The Ordinance defines administrative, economic, functional, and program classifications. However, data are not presented for cross-cutting programs. The common identifier for budget data is the so-called 'Å ifra,' the label in the first column in the budget tables.
Data for the sub-national government and the data on the state-owned enterprises and corporations are available only separately, on their webpages, in different formats, and not always easy to locate.
Sources:
(1) The Ministry of Finance web page with the budget 2020 data, https://mfin.gov.hr/proracun-86/drzavni-proracun-2020-godina/2981
(2)  The executive budget proposal on the Croatian parliament web page, https://www.sabor.hr/prijedlog-drzavnog-proracuna-republike-hrvatske-za-2021-godinu-i-projekcija-za-2022-i-2023-godinu?t=120094&tid=209030
(3) State Treasury application, http://www.drzavna-riznica.hr/upit_po_dobavljacima/
(4) State Treasury Bulk data, https://mfin.gov.hr/UserDocsImages/dokumenti/drzavna-riznica/Dobavljaci%2020212701.zip
(5) The Ordinance on Budget Classifications, 2010/13/20 (consolidated text), http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/1552/208732/hidran.digured.hr/hidrarad/POOPD/Pobirac/SDRH-DOC/MFIN%202020%20Pravilnik%20o%20proracunskim%20klasifikacijama%20-%20procisceni%20tekst%20zaklj%20s%20NN%201-20.pdf

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The main authorizing officers have the obligation to submit to the Ministry of Public Finance, by September 1 of each year, the proposals for the draft budget and its annexes for the next budget year, within the limits of the expenditure and estimates for the next 3 years, accompanied by detailed documentation. (1)  Local government authorities have the same obligation for proposals for consolidated transfers and amounts deducted from some state budget revenues. (2) Also, the budgetary reports are made quarterly and annually on the models of documents issued by the Ministry of Finance. The finding of contraventions and the application of fines are made by the Court of Accounts, the Ministry of Public Finance and other persons empowered for this purpose, according to the law. (3)
Sources: 
(1) Law no. 500/2002 on public finances, https://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocument/37954
(2)Law no. 273/2006 on local public finances, https://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocument/73527
(3) Government Ordinance No. 119 of 31 August 1999 on internal / managerial control and preventive financial control, https://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocument/19169

question: The framework requires a verification process.

question: 2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response: Government Ordinance No. 119 of 31 August 1999 on internal / managerial control and preventive financial control stipulates that the Ministry of Public Finance elaborates methodological norms regarding the general framework of the attributions and exercise of preventive financial control (Article 8). Preventive control is of two kinds: self-control and delegated control. Regarding the first type of control, the public entities, through their managers, have the obligation to organize their own preventive financial control and the record of the commitments within the accounting department. The Ministry of Public Finance approves specific methodological norms regarding the organization and implementation of the preventive financial self-control (Article 9). The Ministry of Public Finance coordinates the system of professional training of persons designated to carry out preventive financial control (Article 10). The delegated preventive financial control is organized and exercised by the Ministry of Public Finance through delegated inspectors. The Minister of Public Finance appoints one or more delegated inspectors for each public institution (Article 12).

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Romania's level of transparency regarding public finances and the publication of budget data is quite high. The Ministry of Public Finance operates a portal on which it uploads all the financial reports of the Romanian public entities in open formats.(1)
According to law no. 69/16 April 2010 on fiscal-budgetary responsibility, Chapter IX on the transparency of fiscal-budgetary policy, the Government and local public authorities have the obligation to make public and maintain in debate for a reasonable period of time all necessary information to assess the implementation of fiscal and budgetary policies, their results and the state of central and local public finances. (2) Within 45 days from the publication of the state budget law and the state social insurance budget law in the Official Gazette of Romania, the Ministry of Public Finance publishes on its own website the data on public debt, according to the European Union methodology, but also financial programming quarterly of state budget expenditures, state social insurance budget and special funds budgets, in economic classification, based on the quarterly budget revenue collection program. And within 55 days of the adoption of the budgets, the Ministry of Public Finance publishes on its website the quarterly estimates regarding the expenditures of the local budgets, the budgets of the self-financed institutions and other components of the general consolidated budget. The classification of indicators on public finances in force was approved by Order 1954 / 16.12.2005, with subsequent amendments and completions, and can be found at:https://mfinante.gov.ro/domenii/bugetul-de-stat/clasificatiile-bugetare (3)
Sources: 
(1) Ministry of Public Finances website, Budget Transparency, https://mfinante.gov.ro/transparenta-bugetara
(2) Law no. 69/16 April 2010 on fiscal-budgetary responsibility
https://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocument/118059
(3)Order no. 1954 of December 16, 2005 for the approval of the Classification of indicators regarding public finances, https://mfinante.gov.ro/domenii/bugetul-de-stat/clasificatiile-bugetare
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The main legal framework for the collection of budgetary information is the Act No. 523/2004 and its amendments On budgetary rules of public administration. (1) 
The Act No. 523/2004 in its part 3, Â§ 6 - (4) states that the Ministry of Finance shall publish the data of the budget in the form of structured data that enables their further automated processing, according to a legislation on access to information and on information technology. 
The guidance does not require the publication of in-year and year-end reports in a structured format but they are, at least partially, available on the site of the Ministry of Finance. (2)

Budget proposal information is published in line with the Council Regulation (EC) No 1466/97 On the strengthening of the surveillance of budgetary positions and the surveillance and
coordination of economic policies (3)- article 4, which however does not require the information to be in the form of structured data.

The Act No. 39/1993 - Â§5, On the Supreme Audit Office of the Slovak Republic, established the mandate of the office, which is apart from others to  prepare an opinion and evaluation on the draft State budget. (4)



(1) Act No. 523/2004 On budgetary rules of public administration. https://www.slov-lex.sk/pravne-predpisy/SK/ZZ/2004/523/20210802
(2) Ministry of Finance. Draft budget plan. https://www.mfsr.sk/sk/financie/institut-financnej-politiky/strategicke-materialy/navrh-rozpoctoveho-planu/navrh-rozpoctoveho-planu.html
(3) European Council. Council Regulation (EC) No 1466/97 On the strengthening of the surveillance of budgetary positions and the surveillance and coordination of economic policies. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/ALL/?uri=CELEX%3A31997R1466
(4) The Act No. 39/1993 On the Supreme Audit Office of the Slovak Republic. https://www.slov-lex.sk/pravne-predpisy/SK/ZZ/1993/39/20200101

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The government publishes budget data on a public-facing website, including some past spending data (1). This budget data is only available via data attached to charts (accessible also via API) but a download of an aggregate dataset is missing.

The rolling spending data is on the web of the Ministry of Finance, in the form of top level every day updates aggregated to monthly reports. (2)

The government also publishes draft budget proposal data on the website of the Ministry of Finance according to the ESA 2010 standard, with spreadsheets available for a download. (3)

Several improvements could be made to the amount of data available as well as to their format, and availability in one place. This is reflected in the Open Budget Survey, where Slovakia's weakest scores for budgetary transparency are in the area of citizen budget (designed to convey key information to the public) and interim reports.(4) 

(1) The Ministry of Finance of SR. Budget.sk. https://rozpocet.sk

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
For budget data, the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 (Pub. L. 93â€“344, title II, Â§â€¯203, July 12, 1974) required the Congressional Budget Office to provide public access to budget data. (1) The Congressional Budget Office provides annual budget projection data and historical budget data. (2) The Congressional Budget Justification Transparency Act was signed into law on September 30, 2021 including a requirement for agencies to post Congressional Budget Justifications to be posted online in a standard format.(3)

For spending data, the Digital Accountability and Transparency Act (DATA Act) was signed into law on May 2014, requiring Federal agencies to establish government-wide financial data standards and report spending data in much more detail. (4) The DATA Act Information Model Schema provides specific spending data standards and the DATA Act Broker validates this data against these standards. (5) The U.S. Department of the Treasury maintains open spending data on usaspending.gov. (6)

Sources:
1. The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GPO-RIDDICK-1992/pdf/GPO-RIDDICK-1992-34.pdf 
2. The Congressional Budget Justification Transparency Act, https://www.cbo.gov/data/budget-economic-data#9
3. The Digital Accountability and Transparency Act, https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/senate-bill/272
4. The DATA Act Information Model Schema, https://www.congress.gov/113/plaws/publ101/PLAW-113publ101.pdf
5. DATA Act Information Model Schema (DAIMS), https://www.fiscal.treasury.gov/data-transparency/DAIMS-v2.1.html
6. USASpending.gov website, https://usaspending.gov

``(iii) in a structured data format, to the extent practicable."

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The United States provides structured data for many stages of the budget process (including individual agency budget justifications, the President's whole federal proposed budget, and Congress' projected budget and actual appropriated funds), and provides agency spending data as open data. (1) (2) (3) (4) In 2021, a new law was passed that requires agencies to provide their budget justifications as open data in a centrally located website. Previously, this information was not structured nor centralized. The DATA Act requires agencies to submit open spending data to the Treasury Department in standard formats that support quality and to some extent international standards. USASpending provides an API, bulk data access, and data visualizations on key topics. Recently, because of the CARES Act legislation, all spending for COVID-19 data was tracked and provided on USASpending. (5) 

While the United States continues to make progress with the availability of their budget and spending data, GAO and agency inspectors general highlight that many agencies continue to fail to report required spending data, or report it with errors. (6) (7) There is great opportunity to build out the standard spending data 'object class' field to provide more transparency on government performance. While there is much public information, specific amendments to budgets or inconsistent spending is not structured and would take some research to assess. Unreported spending data is calculated using the difference in the total obligated amount from the Report on Budget Execution and Budgetary Resources (excluding financing accounts) and the total obligated amount reported by agencies to USAspending.gov in 'Account Breakdown by Program Activity & Object Class' data (also called 'File B' data, see the DAIMS data standards for more information). (8) 

1. Agency Congressional Budget Justification example, https://gsa.gov/cj
2. President's Budget Data, https://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/budget/
3. Congressional Budget Office Data, https://www.cbo.gov/data/budget-economic-data#9
4. Congressional Appropriated Budget Information, https://www.congress.gov/help/appropriations-and-budget
5. USASpending.gov (Reported Spending Data and Explorer), https://usaspending.gov
6. Various GAO reports on the DATA Act, https://www.gao.gov/blog/subject_terms/10866
7. DATA Act Metadata Standard, https://www.fiscal.treasury.gov/data-transparency/DAIMS-v2.1.html

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Under the Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013.1 and the Charter of Budget Honesty Act 1998;2 All government agencies and departments are required to report their annual reports and budgets/expenditures. Since 2018, these reports have been published on the Australian Government Transparency Portal.3

Notable exceptions to these laws are financial planning and reporting deemed to be commercially sensitive in nature or to the detriment of national security. The latter, a justification employed by the Federal Government in defence of its refusal to release details of COVID-19 Vaccine deals.4  

Monthly Financial Statements are available that show the General Budget position.5

Sources:

1. Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013: No. 123, 2013, https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2013A00123

2.Charter of Budget Honesty Act, 1998, https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2014C00438 


3. Australian Government Transparency Portal, https://www.transparency.gov.au/publications

4. Farrell, Paul. Australia is paying hundreds of millions to AstraZeneca for COVID-19 vaccines. But the deal is a 'national security' secret. July 2021. ABC News.

5. Australian Government, Department of Finance. Australian Government General Government Sector Monthly Financial Statements May 2021, https://www.finance.gov.au/publications/commonwealth-monthly-financial-statements/2021/mfs-may

question: 1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response:
The Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013, requires the publishing of annual financial reports by governmnet departments and monthly reports by the Finance Minister, but does not specify in what particular form. There is no evidence of a mandate to publish financial reports on the Transparency portal. 

Part 2-3 of the Public Governance and Accountability Act states that the 'Finance Minister is to publish monthly financial reports'

Part 2-3, Division six requires "the accountable authority of a Commonwealth entity to prepare annual reports for the entity."

Part 2-3, Division 7 states, "is about wholeâ€‘ofâ€‘government reporting by the Finance Minister. It requires the Finance Minister to publish monthly financial reports and table annual consolidated statements in the Parliament. It also requires the Auditorâ€‘General to audit those annual consolidated statements."

Sources: 

 Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013: No. 123, 2013, https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2013A00123

Australian Government Transparency Portal, https://www.transparency.gov.au/publications

response:
There is no specific mention of the form of the data required to be published but under Part 2-3 of the The Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013, the Finance Minister is required to publish financial reports, this includes:  "a corporate plan, and budget estimates, for the entity;".

Government Agencies must:

Section 36  Budget estimates for Commonwealth entities

             (1)  The accountable authority of a Commonwealth entity must:

(a)  prepare the budget estimates covering the entity's activities for each reporting period for the entity, and for any other periods directed by the Finance Minister; and

(b)  give the budget estimates to the Finance Secretary in accordance with any directions under subsection (3)

Source:

Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013: No. 123, 2013, https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2013A00123

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
New Zealand's public finance legal framework is set out in the Public Finance Act 1989(1), Crown Entities Act 2004(2) and the State-Owned Enterprises Act 1986(3). Each Act mandates clear collecting and publishing requirements but makes no mention of structured data. The Treasury's Guide to the Public Finance Act(4) describes the Act and Treasury Instructions, Section 6.2 sets out agency reporting obligations(5). Section 6.2.5 covers reporting by intelligence and security departments.

Sources
1. Public Finance Act 1989. https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1989/0044/latest/DLM160809.html
2. Crown Entities Act 2004. https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2004/0115/latest/DLM329631.html?src=qs
3. State-Owned Enterprises Act 1986 - https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1986/0124/latest/DLM97377.html?src=qs
4. NZ Treasury. 2019. A guide to the Public Finance Act. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/guide/guide-public-finance-act-html
5. NZ Treasury. 2018. Treasury Instructions. Section 6.2. Reporting obligations. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/instructions/treasury-instructions-2018

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
New Zealand publishes all of its Crown financial statements as structured data(1). The data is free of charge and openly licensed with a Creative Commmons CC BY 4.0 International licence. This includes budget data(2), expenditure data(3), social services and community sector(4). For the OBS and GDB 4 funds are classified  as extra budgetary funds: Earthquake Commission, Accident Compensation Commission, NZ Superannuation Fund and the Government Superannuation Fund. With New Zealand's consolidated Accrual accounting these are included in the consolidated Total Crown ex ante and ex post accrual financial statements which also include companies that are partly or fully government owned(5). Budget entries' administrative, economic, functional and programme classifications are generally compatible with international standards(6)(7)(8). The most recent budget update(9) and interim Financial Statements(10) are in May 2021. Machine-readable historical data is available from 1972(11).

Sources
1. NZ Government. 2021. Financial statements. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/financial-statements-government

2. NZ Government. 2020. Budget 2020 Data from the Estimates of Appropriations 2020/21. 
https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/data/budget-2020-data-estimates-appropriations-2020-21

3. NZ Government. 2020. Data and Charts - Financial Statements of the Government of New Zealand for the year ended 30 June 2020. 2020. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/system/files/2020-11/fsgnz-2020-charts-data.xlsx

4. NZ Government. 2021. Social Services and Community Sector - The Estimates of Appropriations for the Government of New Zealand for the Year Ending 30 June 2021. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/budgets/social-services-and-community-sector-estimates-appropriations-government-new-zealand-year-ending-30-june-2021

5. NZ Government. 2021. Financial statements. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/financial-statements-government

6. NZ Government. 2020. Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2020. p.95. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/efu/budget-economic-and-fiscal-update-2020

7. NZ Government. 2021. Data - Core Crown Expense Tables - Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2021.  https://budget.govt.nz/budget/excel/befu2021/befu21-data-expensetables.xls

8. NZ Government. 2020. Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2020. "Forecast Analysis of Expenses by Functional Classification for the years ending 30 June" p.102. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/sites/default/files/2020-07/befu20-v2.pdf

9. NZ Government. 2021. Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2021. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/efu/budget-economic-and-fiscal-update-2021

10. NZ Government. 2021. Interim Financial Statements of the Government of New Zealand for the eleven months ended 31 May 2021.  https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/month-end/interim-financial-statements-government-new-zealand-eleven-months-ended-31-may-2021

11. NZ Government. 2021. Data - Fiscal Time Series Historical Fiscal Indicators 1972-2020. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/information-release/data-fiscal-time-series-historical-fiscal-indicators-1972-2020

question: 1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL(s) where data on the executive budget proposal is located.
response:
As the 2021 Budget statement was on 20 May 2021 (outside the scope of the GDB review period), details of the 2020 budget are provided.

NZ Government. 2020. Budget 2020 Data from the Estimates of Appropriations 2020/21. 
https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/data/budget-2020-data-estimates-appropriations-2020-21

"The Revenue workbook contains details of actual government Crown revenue and capital receipts for the years ended 30 June 2016, 2017, 2018 and 2019; estimated actual government Crown revenue and capital receipts for the year ending 30 June 2020 and budgeted government Crown revenue and capital receipts for the year ending 30 June 2021 as published in Budget 2020.

The Expense workbook contains details of actual government expenditure for the years ended 30 June 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019; estimated actual government expenditure for the year ending 30 June 2020 and budgeted government expenditure for the year ending 30 June 2021 as published in Budget 2020.

Raw data has been made available to allow anyone to filter, sort and manipulate the data for their own purposes. Some examples in the form of pivot tables and charts are also provided.

Information relating to the use of these Excel workbooks is contained within the workbooks on a sheet titled 'Explanation'. More assistance on the use of pivot tables and charts can be obtained from the Excel help system."

response:
There is no reference to structured data in the State-Owned Enterprises Act. See: State-Owned Enterprises Act 1986. Section 16A. Information to be published by boards. State-Owned Enterprises Act 1986. https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1986/0124/latest/LMS84748.html

(1) The board of a State enterprise must publish the following documents on an Internet site maintained by or on behalf of the State enterprise:
(a) the completed statement of corporate intent of the State enterprise:
(b) the annual report and audited financial statements of the State enterprise:
(c) the auditor's report on those financial statements:
(d) the half-yearly report:
(e) the rules of the State enterprise:
(f) any change to those rules:
(g) any notice making a modification to the statement of corporate intent of the State enterprise, and a document that consolidates all modifications into the statement of corporate intent.
(2) Each document referred to in subsection (1)(a) to (d) must be published as soon as practicable after the board delivers that document to the shareholding Ministers.

question: Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: 1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL where administrative classifications are located.
response:
Yes, administrative units accounting for all expenditures are presented.
See: NZ Government. 2019. Estimates of Appropriations for the Government of New Zealand for the Year Ending 30 June 2019
https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/budgets/estimates-appropriations-government-new-zealand-year-ending-30-june-2020

Also, the administrative classification data for the budget year (2018/19) across ALL vote categories:
NZ Government. 2020. Budget 2020 Data from the Estimates of Appropriations 2020/21.  https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/data/budget-2020-data-estimates-appropriations-2020-21

Comment:
The Estimates present all expenses and capital expenditures that the Government plans to incur over the coming budget year for specified outputs within each vote, including capital injections it plans to make to individual departments.
The Estimates are organised on the basis of 10 sector volumes, with each Vote allocated to one sector. All expenses and capital expenditures require an appropriation (Section 4 of Public Finance Act). Appropriations must be supported by Estimates (Section 13 PFA) and Estimates must state, for each appropriation in an Appropriation Act, the Vote to which the appropriation relates, the Minister responsible for the appropriation, and the department responsible for administering the appropriation (Section 14 PFA).

Expenses are on an accrual basis in accordance with GAAP, reflecting the fact that in New Zealand Parliament appropriates funds on an accrual basis. The cash accounting term "expenditure" is not therefore used.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: 1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL where economic classifications are located.
response:
Yes, expenditures are presented by economic classification.
See: NZ Government. 2020. Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2020. p.95. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/efu/budget-economic-and-fiscal-update-2020

While the classification used by NZ Govt to present budget forecasts is not identical to the IMF's economic classification of expenses, the internationally recognised economic classification (see the IMF's Government Finance Statistics Manual 2001, p.63). the economic classification used can be described as generally compatible with international standards. For the relatively small specific areas/categories in which the NZ Govt.'s economic classification differ (e.g. Official Development Assistance" classified as part of "transfer payments and subsidies" rather than using the GFS category of "grants"), sufficient information is available in the NZ accounts to support the necessary adjustments or conversion to the GFS classification.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: 1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL where functional classifications are located.
response:
Yes, expenditures are presented by functional classification.

See: 
1.  Functional classification data at NZ Government. 2021. Data - Core Crown Expense Tables - Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2021.  https://budget.govt.nz/budget/excel/befu2021/befu21-data-expensetables.xls

2. NZ Government. 2020. Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2020. "Forecast Analysis of Expenses by Functional Classification for the years ending 30 June" p.102. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/sites/default/files/2020-07/befu20-v2.pdf

3. NZ Government. 2020. Budget Economic and Fiscal Update 2020. "Core Crown Expense Tables", pp.127-131.
https://www.treasury.govt.nz/sites/default/files/2020-07/befu20-v2.pdf

While COFOG indicates that GSF pension expenses should in principle be apportioned across COFOG functions, it is not clear that doing so in New Zealand's case would generate much benefit. New Zealand budget documents use a classification that presents more categories at the top level than the COFOG, but those categories are clearly compatible with either top-level COFOG categories or COFOG subcategories.

For example,
Transport and Communications is a top-level "Core Crown Expense" category, while Transport and Communications appear as groups within the COFOG Economic Affairs category

question: Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

question: 1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL where program classifications are located.
response:
Yes.

NZ Government. 2020. Estimates of Appropriations for the Government of New Zealand for the Year Ending 30 June 2020
https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/budgets/estimates-appropriations-government-new-zealand-year-ending-30-june-2020

Sample vote-specific document citation:
1. NZ Government. 2020. Estimates of appropriations. Vote Health - Health Sector - Estimates 2019/20. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/estimates/vote-health-health-sector-estimates-2019-20-html

2. Budget year program-level appropriations across ALL vote categories. See: NZ Government. 2020. Budget 2020 Data from the Estimates of Appropriations 2020/21. https://www.treasury.govt.nz/publications/data/budget-2020-data-estimates-appropriations-2020-21

The complete set of Estimates are present across 10 seperate volumes containing vote-specific appropriations. Collectively, the Estimates present all expenses across all votes for each appropriation type as required by law (Section 14 and Section 7.1 of PFA):

Output Expenses (departmental and non-departmental)
Benefit or Related Expenses (non-departmental)
Borrowing Expenses (departmental and non-departmental)
Other Expenses (departmental and non-departmental)
Capital Expenditure (departmental and non-departmental)
Multi-Category Appropriations (departmental and non-departmental)
(unrequited transfer; by borrowing cost; and by other expense,
Output expenses are expenses incurred by departments in supplying a specified category of goods and services (or outputs).

In NZ's output-based system, similarity of goods and services is determined by the nature of the outputs, rather than by similarity of objective or purpose as in a program-based system. However, the categories of appropriations effectively meet the criteria as being programmatic categories at a level of detail below the administrative unit.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The main framework is the Law of Public Access of Information (1). But there is also: 

Open Data Plan (2) covers the publication of finance data. Exist the open national data budget published on a platform.

On the IV Action Plan (OGP) there is a commitment about budget transparency.(3)

Also, year by year the country count with the results from the international survey on budget transparency. It is an initiative promoted by  International Budget Partnership and the local NGO ACIJ.(4)

At subnational level exists open budget information.
The ranking of the cities with open data budget can be found on Index of open data cities web site.(5)


Sources:
(1) Public Access of Information. http://servicios.infoleg.gob.ar/infolegInternet/anexos/265000-269999/265949/texact.htm

(4) Ranking OB Argentina. Last survey for 2019 year.Retrieved from https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/argentina

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Fiscal Responsibility Law guarantees greater control of public accounts, preventing the government from incurring debts or taking out of appropriate loans, as a way of promoting both transparency and inspection (1).
The Capiberibe Law changed the wording of the Fiscal Responsibility Law (LRF) with regard to the transparency of fiscal management, innovating by determining the availability, in real time, of detailed information on the budgetary and financial execution of the Union, the States, the Federal District and Municipalities (2).
The Access to Information Act (3) regulates the right of access to public information. The Transparency Law requires agencies to be proactive in disclosing information. On the other hand, the Access to Information Law guarantees that whoever requests information will receive it, as it also determines that any body must have a space on its website for access to information, where citizens can make requests with facility.
The Open Data Policy was instituted in accordance with the fundamental right of access to information, article 3 of the Access to Information Law, with the aim of promoting the publication of data contained in databases of public administration bodies and entities and making it accessible to citizens to have open access to data produced or accumulated by the Federal Executive Branch. Article 2 determines that publicly accessible data is any data generated or accumulated by the Government that is not under secrecy or restricted access under Law No. 12,527, of November 18, 2011 (4).
Therefore, the framework ensures transparency of fiscal management, access to government information, including municipalities, states and the federal government, the obligation of specific and updated data on the resources received, origin, budget forecast amount, destination, payments and identification of beneficiaries, such as suppliers, programs, actions and projects.

Source:
(1) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/LEIS/LCP/Lcp131.htm
(2) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/LEIS/LCP/Lcp101.htm
(3) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2011-2014/2011/Lei/L12527.htm
(4) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2015-2018/2016/decreto/D8777.htm

The access to information law, article 31, determines that the treatment of personal information must be done in a transparent manner and with respect for the intimacy, private life, honor and image of people, as well as individual freedoms and guarantees. Article 27 determines the classification of confidentiality of information within the scope of public administration. question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The framework that structures the transparency of budget and public expenditure data and information is guaranteed by the fiscal responsibility law (1), the fiscal transparency law (2) and the Access to Information Law (3). With mandatory access to information, the government instituted the National Open Data Policy, which is guided by the National Open Data Infrastructure (4). The National Data Infrastructure (5) guides the publication of data according to international standards, such as the W3C, through the Open Web Data Manual (6). Open data structuring in RDF format provides interoperability and automatic processing of government data. The Federal Budget and Planning System (7) provides Open Budget Data published as linked data (8). The Federal Government's Transparency Portal makes open data available in csv format (9).

Source:
(1) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/LEIS/LCP/Lcp101.htm
(2) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/LEIS/LCP/Lcp131.htm
(3) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2011-2014/2011/Lei/L12527.htm
(4) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2015-2018/2016/decreto/D8777.htm
(5) https://wiki.dados.gov.br/
(6) https://www.w3c.br/pub/Materiais/PublicacoesW3C/Manual_Dados_Abertos_WEB.pdf
(7) https://www1.siop.planejamento.gov.br/mto/doku.php/mto2019:cap1
(8) http://orcamento.dados.gov.br/siopdoc/doku.php/acesso_publico:dados_abertos/#siop_-_dados_abertos
(9) http://transparencia.gov.br/download-de-dados
[Public finance standards aimed at fiscal management responsibility](http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/LEIS/LCP/Lcp101.htm)

question: 1,2;Please briefly explain.
response:
Fiscal responsibility law (1) sets public finance standards aimed at accountability in fiscal management and other measures. The Capiberibe Law (2) establishes public finance standards aimed at the responsibility of fiscal management and other measures to determine the availability, in real time, of detailed information on the budget and financial execution. The Access to Information Law determines the obligation of public bodies and entities to promote, regardless of requirements, the disclosure in an easily accessible place, within the scope of their competence, of information of collective or general interest produced by them or in custody (3). Subsequently, the Open Data Policy in the federal government determines that any data generated or accumulated by the Government under the terms of the access to information law must comply with the policy. The policy is guided by the National Open Data Infrastructure (4).

Source:
(1) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/LEIS/LCP/Lcp101.htm
(2) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/LEIS/LCP/Lcp131.htm

(4) http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2015-2018/2016/decreto/D8777.htm

question: 0,1,2,3;Please, briefly explain your answer.
response:
Pursuant to Law No. 10,180, of February 6, 2001(1) Article 2, the Federal Budget and Planning System is intended to: formulate national strategic planning; formulate national, sectoral and regional economic and social development plans; formulate the multi-year plan, budget guidelines and annual budgets; manage the federal budget and planning process; to promote the articulation with the States, the Federal District and the Municipalities, aiming at the compatibility of norms and tasks related to the various Systems, at the federal, state, district and municipal levels. Federal Budget data is organized by the Federal Budget and Planning System (2).

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The budget law that is published every year is the basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances. This includes budget, public spending, debt and indebtedness.
