question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Open Budget Portal publishes and displays transactional data on the execution of fiscal spending by the Presidency of the Republic, the National Congress, the Judiciary, the Comptroller General of the Republic, the Public Ministry and each of the Ministries and their respective services, in a simple and interactive way. Its objective is to allow citizens, public institutions, civil society and all those interested in the management of public resources to easily know where and how public sector resources are spent.

Sources

question: 0,1,2,3;Please, briefly explain your answer.
response: The Open Budget Portal (https://presupuestoabierto.gob.cl) makes transparent the budget execution data of the aforementioned institutions and that is generated from the Budget Law for the years 2016, 2017, 2018 and 2019 (to date). These transactions are recorded in SIGFE 2 and SIGFE 1, the state accounting systems that record budget execution. By publishing transactional data, they reach the highest level of spending transparency possible, because they openly publish the accrual transaction and its associated data. In addition, they are integrating with the Public Procurement and Contracting Directorate (ChileCompra) to view the detail of the purchase orders associated with accrual transactions, if they have been registered

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Law 1712 of 2014 establishes the Law of Transparency and the Right of Access to National Public Information (1). This Law provides a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances. Nevertheless, it does not refer to data structuration, so there are no reports of structured data of the topics assessed in terms of public finances.

#Sources
(1) https://www.funcionpublica.gov.co/eva/gestornormativo/norma.php?i=56882
[Law of Transparency and the Right of Access to National Public Information](https://www.funcionpublica.gov.co/eva/gestornormativo/norma.php?i=56882)

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Ministry of Finance of Colombia publishes the decree of the presidency of the republic where the general budget of the nation is allocated (1) and the budget execution reports (2) are also in pdf format distributed by months of the year. These documents are in pdf format and are therefore difficult to reuse. Namely, there are no multiple budget datasets. On the contrary, the data are not structured in tables, much less in machine-processable formats.

Efforts have been made to have an economic transparency portal (3) where budget execution can be found by sector, subject, entity, in a structured manner.

## Sources:
(1) https://www.minhacienda.gov.co/webcenter/ShowProperty?nodeId=%2FConexionContent%2FWCC_CLUSTER-154131%2F%2FidcPrimaryFile&revision=latestreleased

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Despite the fact that the law promotes the transparency of budget information, there is no reference in the regulations on the opening of data in this matter. Despite this, there are efforts to make this information published in an open format, for example what was promoted in decree 40199. It is required that the subject of open data be established in budgetary regulations so that the management of this kind of information is more open and transparent.

##Sources:
(1): http://www.pgrweb.go.cr/scij/Busqueda/Normativa/Normas/nrm_texto_completo.aspx?param1=NRTC&nValor1=1&nValor2=84004&nValor3=108193&strTipM=TC

TITLE II. PRINCIPLES AND GENERAL PROVISIONS OF FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATION
SINGLE CHAPTER
ARTICLE 5.- Budgetary principles. For the purposes of the previous article, the following budgetary principles must be addressed:
...
g) Principle of advertising. For the sake of transparency, the budget must be accessible to the public, through the electronic and physical means available.

SECTION II. EXECUTION OF THE REPUBLIC'S BUDGET

ARTICLE 48. Transparency of information. The Ministry of Finance must coordinate the corresponding measures so that the approved budget is widely disseminated by the electronic or physical means available, so that any citizen has access to it.

To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Costa Rica has joined the international standard of open budget data (in English, Open Fiscal Data Package), promoted by the Global Initiative for Fiscal Transparency (GIFT, for its acronym in English, Global Initiative for Fiscal Transparency), in collaboration with the organization Open Knowledge International (OKI) and the BOOST Initiative of the World Bank.

 

On this site you can:

Download the Central Government Income Budget since 2015 according to the Public Sector Income Classifier.
Download the Budget of Expenditures and Execution of the Central Government, since 2015 according to the Classifiers of Expenditures of the Public Sector: Institutional, Economic, Functional, Object of Expenditure and by Source of Financing.
Have data sets in open format (CSV separated by commas) published under the CC BY-SA 4.0 license.
Access monthly updated data sets.
  

In addition, you can consult, download and use the information on the Income and Expenditure Budget of the Republic of Costa Rica

##Sources:
(1): https://www.hacienda.go.cr/contenido/15613-presupuesto-nacional-en-datos-abiertos
(2): https://www.fiscaltransparency.net/es/inicio/

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Organic Law of Transparency and Access to Public Information [1] highlights that all the State institutions that make up the public sector will disseminate information through an information portal or web page, among which is, total information about the annual budget administered by the institution, specifying income, expenses, financing and operating results in accordance with budget classifiers, as well as budget settlement, specifying recipients of the delivery of public resources.

Sources:
[1] - https://www.oas.org/juridico/PDFs/mesicic5_ecu_ane_cpccs_22_ley_org_tran_acc_inf_pub.pdf
Organic Law of Transparency and Access to Public Information

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Organic Budget Law of Guatemala establish norms for the constitution of budgeting, integrated government accounting, treasury and public credit systems.

Guatemala has a legal framework to guide public financial management (PFM); this framework will set how income, debt, budget, spending, and other public finance information, such as budgetary performance indicators or measurements, should be collected, managed, and reported.

The Governmental Agreement No. 50-2021 discuss the publication of Public information under the open data modality 
Article 3. Public information under the open data modality

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
In Honduras, the Ministry of Finance has absolute control of the income and expenditures of public finances of government institutions, including local governments, since it makes the disbursements of some budget items.

There are laws, regulations, guides that offer a complete base to collect and publish financial data, however, the issue of "structured data" is very ambiguous since it is not tacitly exposed in the regulations, but is implicitly defined as "tables" which are relatively text-type files that usually display in rows and columns with titles (2).

To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Open data is available on expenses and budget, the data used by the Ministry of Finance is fed by all government agencies that are obliged to carry out payment transactions to suppliers, it has enough information to make available to the public, however, The open data provided by the Ministry of Finance (SEFIN) is not very easy to use.
The data held in the Financial Administration System (SIAFI) does not have interconnection with other systems of government entities, due to computer security decisions. This limits the link between financial data with any other system that requires a link and have better information.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
This indicator's framework includes laws related to the publication of budget, spending, income, debt, and non-financial indicators. However, the General Law of Government Accountability was preferred to answer element sub-questions from the "Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields," the "Provisions for openness, timing, and structure," and the "Extent" sections since it covers the whole public sector (1). This law provides criteria about the minimum content and periodicity that the income law, proposed budget, in-year reports, and year-end reports should have. Other laws were used to specify additional spending, debt, or performance reports.
The Federal Law on Budget and Fiscal Responsibility was preferred to answer the "Provisions for data quality" since the General Law of Government Accountability only provides general criteria and barely specified responsible government institutions. The Federal Law on Budget and Fiscal Responsibility covers the federal government and state or local government reports when they spend federal resources. Specifics on this matter for state and local government would have to be looked at in each state's law.
To answer if open data is set out in binding policies, laws, or regulations, the keyword "open data" was searched in the whole framework. No results were found, except in the Budget Law from 2020. This law establishes that the Ministry of Finance has to publish open data for the proposed budget, the enacted budget, the quarterly spending reports, and the year-end report (2). However, this law is updated every year, and this article didn't appear in the 2021 budget, so it was answered that there only were requirements to publish data.
The Federal of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility, and the Genera Law of Budget Accountability, were used to answer the economic classification disaggregation level. The only specification found on this matter was in the federal law, which specifies that the enacted budget needs to have an annex with budget distribution by the administrative classification and the economic classification at the chapter and concept levels (3). These levels are the most aggregate ones (4). The General Law on Government Accountability only establishes that budget documents need to have an economic classification.

Sources:
(1) General Law of Government Accountability, article 1. 2008. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LGCG_300118.pdf
(2) 2020 Federal Budget Law, article 2, fractions I-II. 2020. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/abro/pef_2020/PEF_2020_abro.pdf
(3) Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility, article 41, fraction III, b). 2006. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LFPRH_200521.pdf
(4) General Law of Government Accountability, article 46 fraction II b),  47,  48,  53 fraction II,  55, and 61. 2008. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LGCG_300118.pdf

Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

response:
There are five main instruments: 
- The Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility.
- The  Federal Government's budget law from each year.
- The General Law of Government Accountability.
- The Law of Fiscal Discipline of Sub-national Governments.
- The Law of Fiscal Coordination.

question: Elements
Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields:
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Articles from the General Law of Government Accountability specify the summary reports that have to be published by the national and sub-national governments, including the level of disaggregation they need to have (1).

Sources:
(1) General Law of Government Accountability, the fourth title "Government Financial Information and Year-end report," the first chapter "Government Financial Information." 2008. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LGCG_300118.pdf

question: Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Article 61 of the General Law of Government Accountability establishes that the federal government and the sub-national governments should include in their income laws (or equivalent):
a) Income by type of source, including its amount. Sub-national governments should also distinguish income by federal and local funding sources.
b) Debt and other liabilities with third parties.
The same article states that budget laws, or equivalent, of the federal or sub-national governments, should include expenditure by the administrative, economic, functional, program, and geographical classifications. They should also have a list of budget programs and their performance indicators.

question: The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response: Article 63 of the General Law of Government Accountability establishes that the proposed income and budget laws should be published on the government web pages. Article 65 specifies that the approved version of these documents should also be published on government websites.

question: The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
According to article 51 of the General Law of Government Accountability, summary reports from all levels of government should be made at least quarterly and published in a maximum of 30 days after the end of each quarter.
Article 107 of the Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility states that the Executive branch has to send monthly and quarterly reports to the Legislative branch. The quarterly reports have to be delivered in a maximum of 30 days after the end of each quarter. The reports should include a description of the economic context, the relevant fiscal indicators, the main performance indicators of budget programs, the evolution of tax and non-tax income, the evolution of public spending, cross-cutting programs, public debt, infrastructure projects, public-private partnerships, the amounts of the financial requirements of the public sector, and information about the income obtained from investment reports. Monthly reports have to be delivered in a maximum of 30 days after the end of each month. These reports have to include the evolution of public finances, the financial requirements of the financial sector, the amount of internal debt, and the cost of internal and external debt emission.
Article 85 of the Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility and article 48 of the Law of Fiscal Coordination state that sub-national governments have to deliver quarterly reports to the Federal Ministry of Finance and Public Credit about the use of resources they receive from the federal government. These reports include spending disaggregated by the economic classification, spending on investment projects, and performance indicators.
Articles 25, 33 fractions V and VIII, 40, 42, 47, 48, 56, and 57 of the Law of Fiscal Discipline of Subnational Governments establish quarterly reports that the federal government and sub-national governments have to make about sub-national debt and financial responsibilities.

question: The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Article 52 of the General Law of Government Accountability establishes that the summary reports described in the first chapter "Government Financial Information" of the fourth title "Government Financial Information and Year-end report," will be the basis of the in-year and the year-end report.
Article 53 of the same law states that the federal and state governments will publish year-end reports with accounting, budget, and programs by the administrative classification. Year-end reports also have to include qualitative analysis of financial indicators.
Article 54 of the same law establishes that municipalities' year-end report has to include the information mentioned in article 48 of the General Law of Government Accountability.

question: Provisions for data quality:
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The fractions XIV and XVIII, of article 31 of the Organic Law of the Federal Public Administration establish that formulating the proposed budget and the year-end report of the federal government are responsibilities of the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit.
Article 29 and 30 of the Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility establish that government agencies will send their pre-proposed budgets to the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit while the Legislative branch, the Judicial branch, and the autonomous institutions will send their proposed budgets to the referred ministry.
Article 107 of the Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility states that the federal Executive branch will send quarterly reports to the federal Legislative branch through the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. Government agencies have to send the necessary information to referred ministry so it can consolidate the reports.
Articles 85 of the Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility and 48 of the Law of Fiscal Coordination say that subnational governments will send reports their quarterly reports through the information system established by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. The latter ministry will include this information in the quarterly reports sent to the Legislative Branch.

question: The framework requires a verification process.
2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response:
Article 107 of the Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility establishes that the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit will consolidate the information for the quarterly reports. The methodology of this report has to enable comparing information between several years.
The first article of the Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility mentions that the Supreme Audit Institution will audit the strict compliance to this law. Article 6 of the same law states that the Ministry of Public Administration will also inspect compliance.
Article 72 of the General Law of Government Accountability mentions that the Supreme Audit Institution (and equivalent in the state government) will verify that sub-national governments send their spending reports and the quality and consistency of the information delivered.

question: Provisions for openness, timing, and structure:
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Article 51 of the General Law of Budget Accountability establishes that the whole public sector has to prepare summary reports at least quarterly and publish them 30 days before the end of each period.
Article 107 of the Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility mentions that the federal Executive branch will deliver monthly and quarterly reports to the Legislative branch related to income, spending, debt, and performance indicators. Article 85 of the same law and 48 of the Law of Fiscal Coordination require quarterly reports about sub-national spending with resources they received from the federal government.

question: The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The General Law of Government Accountability objective is setting general criteria for government accountability, and to harmonize financial reports across the public sector (1).
This law establishes: a) criteria for summary reports in the first chapter of the fourth title; b) criteria for the year-end report in the second chapter of the fourth title; and c) criteria for the income law and the proposed and enacted budget second chapter of the fifth title. The referred criteria include the collection of information related to debt and performance indicators.

Sources:
(1) General Law of Government Accountability, article 1. 2008. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LGCG_300118.pdf

question: Extent
How comprehensive is the coverage of laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?
response: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national, and local government.

question: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g., defence sector.)
response: No, the General Law of Public Accountability covers all of the public sector and establishes the content and criteria to publish summary reports, the proposed budget, and the year-end report. Although the Federal Law of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility only covers central government agencies, national public corporations, and sub-national governments when they spend resources received from the federal government, so it doesn't cover spending done with resources they obtained by their means.

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Several datasets are available to answer sub-questions from this indicator, as can be seen in the "Kinds of data" sub-question. However, the budget spending dataset from the first quarter of 2021 was used to answer most of the "Data fields and quality" and the "Data openness, timing, and structure" sections. The reason is that this dataset covers all of the budget programs and classifications, has all of the federal government agencies, social security institutions, state-owned enterprises, some public corporations, and transfers to local governments. This dataset is regularly updated and has the necessary identifiers to connect with information regarding investment projects, performance indicators, and procurement processes.
Regarding the question about open official tools available to explore the data, the answer was "No" even when Mexico has the Open Fiscal Data Package on its budget transparency platform (1). The reason is that the viewer is updated until 2019 while the dataset has a 2021 update.
The Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) has not evaluated Mexico (2), so this research used normative documents that set classifications to see if they were based on international standards. The administrative classification is based on the Government Finance Statistics Manual (GFSM) 2011 and Mexico's system of national accounts (3). The economic classification also follows the GFSM and Mexico's system of National Accounts (4). The Functional Classification follows the Classification of Functions of Government, GFSM 2001, and Mexico's system of national accounts (5). The program classification doesn't mention if it follows any standard (6), but the sub-question was answered as "Yes" using the PEFA criteria, which states that the program classification may substitute for subfunctional classification it has a level of detail corresponding to the subfunctional classification (7).

Sources:
(1) https://www.transparenciapresupuestaria.gob.mx/es/PTP/datos_presupuestarios_abiertos
(2) https://development-data-hub-s3-public.s3.amazonaws.com/ddhfiles/94569/wb_fmis_obd_dataset.xlsx
(3) Acuerdo por el que se emite la clasificaciÃ³n administrativa, I. IntroducciÃ³n. 2011. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_02_002.pdf
(4) Acuerdo por el que se emite la ClasificaciÃ³n EconÃ³mica de los Ingresos, de los Gastos y del Financiamiento de los Entes PÃºblicos, II. Concepto. 2011. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_12_001.pdf
(5) Acuerdo por el que se emite la clasificaciÃ³n funcional del gasto, A. Aspectos Generales. 2010. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_02_003.pdf
(6) Acuerdo por el que se emite la clasificaciÃ³n programÃ¡tica (Tipologia genera). 2013. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_02_004.pdf
(7) PEFA. 2016. Framework for assessing public financial management. PEFA Secretariat. https://www.pefa.org/sites/pefa/files/news/files/PEFA-Framework_English.pdf

question: The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL where these identifiers are located, and briefly explain your answer.
response:
Budget datasets have a variable called "ID_CLAVE_CARTERA" which contains an identifier for the federal government investment projects. This identifier serves to search data on the investment projects dataset (1).
It also can be used to connect investment projects with procurement processes. Mexico's budget transparency website has a section about open infrastructure where individual investment projects link to procurement processes (2).
The budget transparency platform has a contract execution dataset on spending commitments, which connects with investment datasets by the investment project identifier. The latter allows linking investment projects with some procurement information such as the name and identifier of the procuring entity and the supplier (3).

Sources

question: 0,1,2,3;Please, briefly explain your answer.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Law 1535/1999 on the Financial Administration of the State delineates the processes to create, amend, structure, and understand the annual general budget and its relevant actors and responsibilities (1). Art. 10 of the Access to Information Law 5282/2014 states that the Executive Power must publish electronically and keep updated a database with the National General Budget, its original draft proposal to Congress, and budget execution, among other clearly defined requirements detailed in paragraph (a) (2).

To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?

There are functional, program, and administrative classifications; those sections were filled thanks to an interview with the Finance Ministry's Accounting and Open Data Director, MarÃ­a Teresa AgÃ¼ero (4).

question: 1,2;Please provide a URL(s) for where this data can be found.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Article 26 of the Law on the Budgetary System of the Republic of Armenia ensures the publicity of the development, discussion, and approval of the draft state budget, implementation of the state budget law and its verification (1). The Ministry of Finance sets out guidelines and provides templates for collecting and reporting data on state and community budgets (2). 
In November 2019, the Government of Armenia approved the strategy and action plan to implement the Public Finance Management (PFM) system reform for 2019-2023 (3). The reform will improve the efficiency of the public expenditure management system and the quality of services provided (4). 

Sources
(1): The Law on the Budgetary System of the Republic of Armenia, 1997 http://www.parliament.am/law_docs/210797HO137eng.pdf
(2): The Order N254-N of the Ministry of Finance of March 13, 2019 
https://minfin.am/website/images/website/iravakan_akter/hramanner/byujetayin/254-N%20(2).pdf
(3): The Strategy and the Action Plan of Public Finance Management (PFM) System Reform for 2019-2023
https://www.e-gov.am/gov-decrees/item/33133/
(4): https://www.gov.am/en/news/item/9647/
[The Law on the Budgetary System of the Republic of Armenia](http://www.parliament.am/law_docs/210797HO137eng.pdf)
[The Order N254-N of the Ministry of Finance of March 13, 2019](https://minfin.am/website/images/website/iravakan_akter/hramanner/byujetayin/254-N%20(2).pdf)
[The Strategy and the Action Plan of Public Finance Management (PFM) System Reform for 2019-2023](https://www.e-gov.am/gov-decrees/item/33133/)

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
According to the Article 26 (Publicity of the State Budget) of the Law on the Budgetary System of the Republic of Armenia, the quarterly plan of state budget implementation is published within 15 days after being confirmed by the Cabinet; and within one month after the end of each quarter, the Cabinet publishes information on quarterly implementation of the state budget.

In November 2019, the Government approved the strategy and action plan to implement the Public Finance Management (PFM) system reform for 2019-2023.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The legal framework of public finance and the publication of the information related to them are regulated with two core legal acts: Law on Budget system (1), Law on Chamber of accounts (3), and Law on getting information (2). 
According to the Law on Budget system, the draft law on the state budget for the next budget year shall be published in the press within 10 days from the date of its submission to the Parliament of the Republic of Azerbaijan together with the documents specified in Articles 12.1.1 - 12.1.10 (this document includes income, debt, budget, spending, and other public financial information, etc.) of this Law.  (Article 14) (16.12.2016 No462-VQD) (1)
The quarterly report on the execution of the state budget shall be published in the media (Article 20.2) (16.12.2016 No462-VQD) (1). Following this rule, The Ministry of Finance publishes monthly reports.
According to the Freedom of Information Law, the owner of public finance information (state bodies, state-owned companies, etc.) should disclose budget forecasts, reports on the execution of the state budget, and consolidated budget (Article 29) (30.09.2005 â„– 1024-IIQ) (2). There is no common practice for fulfilling these requirements. Some public organizations, including the Ministry of Finance, systematically open public finance information. The law does not specify if such information should be machine-readable or not. Therefore, it is common that organizations to publish PDF files rather than machine-readable format.
The Cabinet of Ministers' Regulation on 'Information on the annual financial activities of budget organizations, public legal entities established on behalf of the state, extra-budgetary state funds, 30 percent or more of shares (shares) owned by the state, as well as the use of funds provided from the state budget or property allocated to them Rules for Disclosure of Information in Internet Information Resources'  regulates forms off disclosed information.  According to this rule, reports should be published no later than April 30 of the following year (6.11.2018 No504) (4) 
Conclusion
For all public finance, the public entities should disclose financial reports on their web pages. Common practice is to publish basic financial information as a PDF file. There is no source for detailed budget and spending information.

Source
Links accessed on 24 July 2021
(1) Law on Budget system: http://e-qanun.az/framework/1126
(2) http://e-qanun.az/framework/11142
(3) http://e-qanun.az/framework/39922
(4) http://e-qanun.az/framework/40775
(5) Annual statistical report of the government budget and spending: https://www.stat.gov.az/source/finance/
(6) Monthly budget information published by the Ministry of Finance: http://www.maliyye.gov.az/static-page/periodic-reports

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
There are two main sources for public financial information: The State Statistical Committee and The Ministry of Finance. Both sources do not provide detailed information about public finance. Generalized information does exist in both sources. The ministry provides monthly reports in PDF format (1) (2). General report on execution of the state budget does exist in PDF with relatively better details. The PDF files have tabular data, unfortunately, the Ministry does not publish it in any tabular data format (3). The ministry informs that it is possible to get such information in an Excel file with an information request (maliyye.gov.az/site/write-letter). But, the procedure is to publish them as PDF.

Basic information about the state debt exists only in text format (4).

Source

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
National legislation such as the Budget Code (1) and Access to Information law (2) provide a legal framework for collecting and publishing data on public finances. The framework covers the entire public sector. Additional provisions regulate how income, debt, budget, spending, and other public finance information, such as budgetary performance indicators, should be collected, managed, and reported.

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
Elements
Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields:
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
According to the Article 27 of Budget Code of the Republic of Kazakhstan all budget information must be provided as structured data:
Unified budget classification shall include:

      1) a classification of budget revenues;

      2) a functional classification of budget expenditures;

      3) an economic classification of expenditures.
Article 30. Economic classification of budget expenditures

      1. Economic classification of budget expenditures is the grouping of budget expenditures on economic performance, reflecting the operations conducted by state institutions for the implementation of budget programs.

      2. Grouping of economic classification of budget expenditures consists of the category, class, subclass and specificity.

      The category shall group the spending on economic grounds. The class and subclass shall group expenditures on the main types of transactions conducted by state institutions. Specificity determines the type of operations carried out by state institution for the implementation of the budget program.

      3. The structure of the specifics of economic classification of budget expenditures shall be developed and approved by the central authorized body on budget planning.

Following link contains information on budget execution and Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification (table 10 and table 11) https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/minfin/documents/details/186213?lang=ru

      At the same time, the revenues are set out by categories, classes and subclasses, and the expenditures are set out by functional groups, administrators of the budget programs and the budget programs. The section "financing the (the use of surplus) budget deficit" shall be presented by the total amount.

      The basic expenses set out in the expenses for the second and third years of the planning period by the functional groups, administrators of the budget programs and the budget programs, and the expenses for new initiatives are reflected in a budget program.

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
According to the Open Budget Survey 2019 (1), Kazakhstan's budget transparency score is 58 out of 100. Budget data is available from multiple sources. Budget data is available on governmental websites (2). The development of an online "Open Budgets" portal (3) improved the accessibility of budget data at the budget proposal stage. All governmental agencies at the national and subnational levels publish information about their budget at each stage of the budget process (draft, approved budget, report). In general, consolidated information on the budget is regularly published by the Ministry of Finance (2). There are also examples of initiatives to publish budget data from non-governmental organizations. For example, the project "Open Budget Interactive Map" (4) is aimed at disclosing budget spending at the sub-national level and contains information about the allocated budget funds for public schools, hospitals, etc. The project was initiated by the NGO "Public Foundation for Development of Parliamentarism in Kazakhstan" in collaboration with the Anticorruption agency.Â 

Sources: 

1. Open Budget Index
https://www.internationalbudget.org/sites/default/files/country-surveys-pdfs/2019/open-budget-survey-kazakhstan-2019-en.pdf

2. The finance ministry website 
https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/minfin/activities/448?lang=ru

3. Open budget portal 
https://budget.egov.kz/

4. Open Budget Interactive Map https://publicbudget.kz/ru

5. Open Budget
https://openbudget.kz/class/

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
There are two laws which require state bodies to publish information on public finance: the Law on access to information  held by state bodies and local self-government bodies of the Kyrgyz Republic dated July 27, 2016 No. 152, and the Budgetary Code dated May 16, 2016 No. 59. There is a specific outline of information which must be published by state bodies, along with a timeframe. There are also restrictions outlined in the Law of access to information (article 5).

Sources: 
1) Law of Kyrgyz Republic, dated December 28, 2006 No. 213 "On access to information held by state bodies and bodies of local self-government of the Kyrgyz Republic". http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/202010
2) Budgetary Code dated of May 16, 2016 No. 59. http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/111338
3) "Open budget" open data state owned web-portal https://budget.okmot.kg/ru

[LAW OF THE KYRGYZ REPUBLIC On amendments to the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic "On access to information under the jurisdiction of state bodies and local self-government bodies of the Kyrgyz Republic"](http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/111431?cl=ru-ru)

There are two laws which require state bodies to publish information on public finance: Law on access to information  held by state bodies and local self-government bodies of the Kyrgyz Republic dated July 27, 2016 No. 152, and the Budgetary Code dated May 16, 2016 No. 59.  

According to the law on access to information, restriction of access to information is established for the purposes of: protection of national security, public order, protection of health or morality of the population, protection of the rights and freedoms of others. 

Restriction of access is established also in relation to information: on state secrets determined by the law on the protection of state secrets, of a personal nature, determined by the law on information of a personal nature, on operational-search activity, on criminal proceedings in cases established by law, containing a secret protected by law (commercial, banking, notarial, medical, lawyer's and other).

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
There are several laws, regulations, and guidance that provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances. Especially, those legal acts aim at increasing transparency, public participation, and public oversight in the use of state and local government funds and assets. Legal acts include the Law on Budget, the Law on Law on Information Transparency and Right to Access Information, the Law on Procurement of Goods, Works and Services with State and Local Funds, and the Law on Glass Wallet.  In addition that, there are two main regulations (guidance) including 'Public Investment Project Planning, Budgeting, Monitoring, and Reporting' and 'Prioritizing and Evaluation Public Investment Projects'(1). Also, the enactment of the Law on Glass Account, advanced efforts toward fiscal transparency and citizen engagement. Especially, the Law on Glass Account resulted in the creation of two web portals for public investments(2) and public funds. The Ministry of Finance administers web portals and publishes data on government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing. Therefore, it's apparent that legal frameworks that provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances are well-established in Mongolia. Although the two platforms are fully operational, some data are missing due to the lack of routine monitoring. Therefore,  enforcing is crucial in Mongolia. 

Sources: 
(1). A list of legal acts. Ministry of Finance. https://mof.gov.mn/data_grid/budget/124/2017
(2) Public Investment web portal. Ministry of Finance. https://publicinvestment.gov.mn/
(3) Public Fund web portal. Ministry of Finance. https://shilendans.gov.mn/

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response: In Mongolia, the Law on Budget, Law on Information Transparency and Right to Access Information, and Law on Procurement of Goods, Works, and Services with State and Local Funds provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances. In accordance with those laws, several regulations (guidance) including 'Public Investment Project Planning, Budgeting, Monitoring, and Reporting' and 'Prioritizing and Evaluation Public Investment Projects' are approved by the Government of Mongolia and relevant government authorities. Also, the adoption of the Law on Glass Account in 2014, advanced efforts toward fiscal transparency and citizen engagement. There are two main government platforms including https://publicinvestment.gov.mn/ and https://shilendans.gov.mn/ which are the main websites (platforms) in which government publishes data on public finances.

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
There are three web portals that share data on the government budget and spending including https://shilendans.gov.mn, http://www.iltod.gov.mn, and https://publicinvestment.gov.mn. Three web portals are administered by the Ministry of Finance(1). But all of the government budget and spending in the three web portals are unavailable as open data as of October 2021. But the portal, 'http://iltod.mof.gov.mn/opendata' is under the construction.  Instead, the National Statistics Office of Mongolia (NSO) shares the historical and up-to-date data with the public. Also, the government budget and spending information are available as open data on the NSO's website(2). Overall, types of data related to the government budget and spending are varied and transparent to some extent. Also, data timing and openness are sufficient. However, there are some limitations related to the data formats and structure; therefore, users are not able to explore the data further and utilize it.  

Sources: 
(1). Ministry of Finance. https://mof.gov.mn/data_grid/budget/124/2017
(2) Government budget and spending, National Statistics Office of Mongolia. 
http://1212.mn/Stat.aspx?LIST_ID=976_L08&type=tables

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Open Budget Survey 2019 ranking shows that, in terms of budgetary transparency, the Republic of Moldova registers the score of 57 points out of 100. The result indicates a limited disclosure of information on budget documents and places the Republic of Moldova on the 39th place out of 117 countries that were included in the evaluation. OBS 2019 shows an increase in the detail of budget documents, in particular annual reports, although the authorities remain lagging behind in preparing and publishing mid-year reports and also in terms of budgetary discipline.(1)

The BOOST database of government spending has been constantly but slowly updated. The latest data from BOOST is from 2019, as the ministry does not have enough human and financial resources to manage the process at a faster pace. (2)

Data on budget execution is being published by the Ministry of Finance on the open data portal date.gov.md. The data is updated on a monthly basis. (3)

Users can navigate through data about National Public Budget through an interactive tool data that creates data visualization on budget execution. The portal was launched by the Ministry of Finance. (4)

Sources:
1) Press release Open budget survey 2019 Moldova 
https://www.expert-grup.org/ro/activitate/comunicate-de-presa/item/1962-potrivit-open-budget-survey-2019-republica-moldova-bate-pasul-pe-loc-la-capitolul-transparentei-bugetare
2) Public expenditure database Boost
https://mf.gov.md/ro/content/analiza-cheltuielilor-2009-2019
3) Data on budget execution 
https://date.gov.md/ckan/ro/dataset/15071-raport-privind-executarea-bugetului-public-national
4) Budget execution data visualization
https://buget.mf.gov.md/ro#bpn

The LAW ON PUBLIC FINANCE OF THE REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN (1) stipulates that after the approval of the state fiscal and tax policy for the period of budget planning, the budget document is published annually. question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Budget Codex (Articles 28, 59-61) defines the legal framework of budget openness. (1). The Openness of Public Money Spending Law (2015) is operational and all budget government spending should be published (2). According to the Access to Public Information Law, public finances data should be published as open data. Some data is included in the dataset lists of the Open Data Decree (3).  In 2016 the official concept of the transparent budget project was approved by the government (4). 

Sources (Accessed 1-8 August 2021)


(1) The Budget Codex: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2456-17#n550
(2) The Openness of Public Money Spending Law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/183-19/print  
(3) The Open Data Decree: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/835-2015-%D0%BF#Text  
(4) The transparent Budget Concept: https://www.kmu.gov.ua/npas/248848450

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
According to the Open Budget Survey (the latest 2019), Ukraine has 63% budget transparency (1). There is going to be OBS 2021. But they have promised to publish it soon (2). 

There are some details about the availability of some data in the questionnaire to this survey (3). The budget classification is mostly developed based on international standards (4). Data on extra budget funds is partly available.

Meanwhile, data about budgets are allocated in different formats and sources, primarily in bad-quality tables. Only spending data is of good level quality, provide access to data via API (5). Other budget data is collected and presented on the Open Budget service, but not all data is there (6)

Sources (Accessed 1-8 August 2021): 

(1) Open Budget Survey 2019: Ukraine: https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/ukraine
(2) OBS 2021 plan: http://www.ipp-jcs.org/en/open-budget-survey-2/
(3) Open Budget Survey country questionnaire Ukraine: https://www.internationalbudget.org/sites/default/files/2020-05/ukraine-202002150030.pdf
(4) Budget Codex: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2456-17
(5) Spending: https://confluence.spending.gov.ua/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=65547
(6) Open Budget: https://openbudget.gov.ua/

question: The framework requires a verification process.

The final accounts, audited and accompanied by the conformity reports allow for the annual verification of compliance with budgetary authorizations as well as and the evolution of the State's assets. These accounts are presented to Parliament and published before the adoption of the next budget.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Ghana Public Financial Management Act,2016 Act 921 provides a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances. It covers Responsibilities and Roles for Public Financial Management, Macroeconomic and Fiscal Policies, Budget Preparation, Approval and Management, Contingency Fund, Sinking Fund and Debt Servicing, Cash and Asset Management, Public Debt Management, Accounts and Audit, Miscellaneous Provisions. The Act regulates the financial management of the public sector within a macroeconomic and fiscal framework.

This law requires publication of data on public finances but not as open data. There are guidelines in this Act regarding what type information / data to be included in the annual budget.

Source:
(1) Source:
https://www.mofep.gov.gh/sites/default/files/acts/PUBLIC-FINANCIAL-MANAGEMENT-ACT-2016.pdf

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
Ghana has Public Financial Management Act, 2016 an "Act to regulate the financial management of the public sector within a macroeconomic and fiscal framework; to define responsibilities of persons entrusted with the management and control of public funds, assets, liabilities and resources, to ensure that public funds are sustainable and consistent with the level of public debt; to provide for accounting and audit of public funds and to provide for related matters. 
Section 42 of the Public Finance Management Act, 2016  outlines the publication of government debt and finance arrangements. The public Debt Management Office is mandated to publish its information every half quarter and annual report to parliament annually.


Source:
https://www.mofep.gov.gh/sites/default/files/acts/PUBLIC-FINANCIAL-MANAGEMENT-ACT-2016.pdf

Section 72, Annual report to Parliament of the Public Financial Management Act, 2016 outlines a set of information to be provided in the report. It states that . (1) The Public Debt Management Office shall, in respect of each preceding year, prepare an annual report on (a) borrowings and other government debt management operations,
(b) guarantee and lending activities of Government, and
(c) other finance arrangements entered into by Government.
(2) The annual report shall include
(a) information on the debt management strategy and the
rationale for the strategy;
(b) information on the contribution of the debt management
strategy and the execution of the strategy in achieving the
debt management objectives under section 58;
(c) a list of outstanding government debt;
(d) a list of outstanding government guarantees, including
Public Financial Management Act, 2016
45
 Act 921
(i) the amount and beneficiaries of the guarantees, and
(ii) an assessment of the fiscal risk embedded in the
guarantees;
(e) a list of lending operations, including outstanding amounts
and beneficiaries of the loans and an assessment of the credit
risk of the loans; and
(f) a list of outstanding supplier's credit agreements and
finance lease agreements and the financial terms of the agreements.

Source:
https://www.mofep.gov.gh/sites/default/files/acts/PUBLIC-FINANCIAL-MANAGEMENT-ACT-2016.pdf

question: The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Section 20 and 21 Guidelines for preparation of annual budget of the Public Financial Management Act, 2016 sets out guidelines on approval to be provided following these laid down procedures and information: 

20. (1) The Minister shall
(a) subject to Cabinet approval, issue guidelines for the preparation of the budget for each financial year; and
(b) circulate copies of the guidelines to each covered entity not
later than the 30th of June of every year.
(2) The guidelines shall include
(a) the economic outlook for the country;
(b) revenue forecasts;
(c) fiscal targets in relation to the fiscal principles, particularly,
the need to achieve sustainable levels of public debt and
fiscal balance;
(d) medium-term fiscal framework including key assumptions;
(e) the multiple year ceilings for each covered entity in line with
the Fiscal Strategy Document;
(f) the ceilings on the required number of staff for each covered
entity and the cost of appropriation for the relevant year
for the public service;
(g) the reconciliation of any change to the previous MediumTerm Expenditure Framework arising from the discretionary, policy changes, baseline parameters, and re-allocation of
expenditure items;
(h) the selection criteria for investment projects, including
provision for linking forward recurrent expenditure
estimates to investments;
(i) the ceilings for the preparation of the budget estimates of
local government authorities;
(j) details of expenditure under statutory funds and alignment
and co-ordination of statutory funds with fiscal objectives,
targets and other aspects of the budget; and
(k) any other information required from a covered entity to
enable the Minister prepare the annual budget in accordance
with the requirements of section 21.

Source:
https://www.mofep.gov.gh/sites/default/files/acts/PUBLIC-FINANCIAL-MANAGEMENT-ACT-2016.pdf

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Ministry of Finance publishes the national budget for the government of Ghana. These budgets are published in both portable document format (PDF) and Excel. This budget provides the basis for government spending at any specific fiscal period. These budgets are updated and available for free for download with no license attribution to it.

Government budget and spending information is available as structured open data, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects, amended budgets or amendments of the enacted budget, on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, on the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, social security spending etc.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
In the assessment of this indicator, we find that the laws of Kenya provide a clear and comprehensive framework for public bodies to publish information on public finance data as required by the Constitution of Kenya and the Public Finance Management Act 2012. This is to ensure transparent and effective management of public funds, promoting accountability and ensuring that all this information of budgeting and spending  is easily accessible to all citizens
Sources
1. The Constitution of Kenya 2010

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
The  laws in Kenya that provide comprehensive frameworks on the collection and publication of public finance reports  are  in (1) the Constitution of Kenya,  2010:
 Article 35 (3) guarantees access to information, "The State shall publish and publicize any important information affecting the nation." 
Article 201 requires that "The following principles shall guide all aspects of public finance in the Republicâ€” (a) there shall be openness and accountability, including public participation in financial matters"
Article 226 (a) states  that  " the keeping of financial records and the auditing of accounts of all governments and other public entities prescribe other measures for securing efficient and transparent fiscal management." 
The Constitution gives rise to (2) the Public Finance Management Act, 2012 whose objective is to ensure thatâ€”
 (a) "public finances are managed at both the national and the county levels of government in accordance with the principles set out in the Constitution; and
(b) public officers who are given responsibility for managing the finances are accountable to the public for the management of those finances through Parliament and County Assemblies."
 
The regulations of collection and publication of public finances in Kenya can be found in  the Public Finance Management Act, 2012:
Section 80 (2) (b) a summary ofâ€” (i) the appropriation accounts and statements prepared by accounting officers under section 81; and (ii) the statements prepared by receivers of revenue under section 82; 
Section 81 (1) At the end of each financial year, the accounting officer for a national government entity shall prepare financial statements in respect of the entity.  

Sources 
1. The Constitution of Kenya 
http://parliament.go.ke/sites/default/files/2017-05/The_Constitution_of_Kenya_2010.pdf
2. The Public Finance Management Act 2012
http://kenyalaw.org:8181/exist/rest//db/kenyalex/Kenya/Legislation/English/Acts%20and%20Regulations/P/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%20Cap.%20412C%20-%20No.%2018%20of%202012/docs/PublicFinanceManagementAct18of2012.pdf

question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
response: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance.

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
response:
the laws do not explicitly state that the information must be in open data or any particular format or any specific machine-readable format.
The laws that require the publishing of public finance reports as open data are contained in the (1) the Constitution of Kenya,  2010,  Article 35 (3) which guarantees access to information, 
"The State shall publish and publicize any important information affecting the nation." 
Article 201 requires that "The following principles shall guide all aspects of public finance in the Republicâ€” (a) there shall be openness and accountability, including public participation in financial matters"

(2) The Public Finance Management Act 2012 which requires several Government bodies to publish public finance data such as in Section 10(1) "The Parliamentary Budget Office shallâ€”(f) subject to Article 35 of the Constitution, ensure that all reports and other documents produced by the Parliamentary Budget Office are prepared, published and publicized not later than fourteen days after production; and (g) report to the relevant committees of Parliament on any Bill that is submitted to Parliament that has an economic and financial impact, making reference to the fiscal responsibility principles and to the financial objectives set out in the relevant Budget Policy Statement."

Section 26 (9) "The National Treasury shall publish and publicise the Budget Policy Statement not later than fifteen days after submission of the Statement to Parliament."

Section 27 "Not later than seven days after the Budget Review and Outlook Paper has been approved by Cabinet, the National Treasury shallâ€” (a) submit the Paper to the Budget Committee of the National Assembly to be laid before each House of Parliament; and (b) publish and publicise the Paper not later than fifteen days after laying the Paper before Parliament."

Section 32 (3) "Not later than two months after the end of each financial year, the Cabinet Secretary shall publish and publicise a report giving details of the guarantees given by the national government during that year."

Section 33 (4) "Within fourteen days after the debt strategy paper is submitted to Parliament under this section, the Cabinet Secretary shall submit the statement to the Commission on Revenue Allocation and the Intergovernmental Budget and Economic Council and publish and publicise the statement. "

Section 46 states, "Within twenty-one days after the end of each month, the Cabinet Secretary shall publish in the Gazette a statement of actual revenues collected by category and net exchequer issues by the National Treasury."
Section 80 (2) (b) a summary ofâ€” (i) the appropriation accounts and statements prepared by accounting officers under section 81; and (ii) the statements prepared by receivers of revenue under section 82" 
Section 81 (1) "At the end of each financial year, the accounting officer for a national government entity shall prepare financial statements in respect of the entity. " 

Sources 
1. The Constitution of Kenya 
http://parliament.go.ke/sites/default/files/2017-05/The_Constitution_of_Kenya_2010.pdf
2. The Public Finance Management Act 2012
http://kenyalaw.org:8181/exist/rest//db/kenyalex/Kenya/Legislation/English/Acts%20and%20Regulations/P/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%20Cap.%20412C%20-%20No.%2018%20of%202012/docs/PublicFinanceManagementAct18of2012.pdf

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response: In the assessment of this indicator  we find that the laws of Kenya give a comprehensive framework that requires the collection and publication of consolidated public finance reports and data by relevant Government bodies in (1) the Constitution of Kenya,2010, (2) the Public Finance Management Act 2012 and this ensures full transparency and accountability. Citizens are made aware of the current state of affairs, how the government is acquiring its revenue, and the spending in a clear and annual basis.

[The National Treasury and Planning - The Budget Summary for the Fiscal Year 2021/22 and Supporting Information](https://www.treasury.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/29.04.2021_Final-Budget-Summary_TP.pdf)

question: Existence
Is this data available online in any form?
response: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.

question: 1,2;Please provide a URL(s) for where this data can be found.
response:
The government of Kenya avails this information through:
The (1)Central Bank of Kenya provides the Government Financial Statistics which covers the central government fiscal data including revenues, expenditures, deficits and deficit financing, and stock of public debts.  The Statistics are provided in several machine-readable and downloadable formats, that is, Excel, CVS, and PDF.
(2) The Ministry of National Treasury and Planning publishes the Budget Summary on Revenue and Expenditure in accordance with the Public Finance Management Act 2012 which requires submission of  Budget Estimates of the Government to the National Assembly for the next financial year at least two months before the end of the financial year. 
(3) The World Bank Group through the Kenya BOOST Public Expenditure Database publishes public expenditure data that provides datasets on two decades of spending information at the national and county governments in Kenya

Sources
1. The Central Bank of Kenya 
https://www.centralbank.go.ke/statistics/government-finance-statistics/
2. THE NATIONAL TREASURY AND PLANNING: THE BUDGET SUMMARY FOR THE FISCAL YEAR 2021/22 AND THE SUPPORTING INFORMATION
https://www.treasury.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/29.04.2021_Final-Budget-Summary_TP.pdf
3. Kenya Boost Public Expenditure Database
https://datacatalog.worldbank.org/dataset/kenya-boost-public-expenditure-database

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Public finance in Morocco is governed by the Finance Law, which is defined and subject to the organic law 130-13 (1). The law defines the legal and technical procedures required to implement Finance Laws in Morocco. Article 66, mentions the required documents that should be provided for the Government Budget, and spending. The Finance law execution report should be provided to the court of auditors, parliament, and to the Government.

Source: 
(1) http://lof.finances.gov.ma/sites/default/files/loi_organique_130-30_fr18.pdf

response:
Public finance in Morocco is governed by the Finance Law, which is defined and subject to the organic law 130-13 (1). The law defines the legal and technical procedures required to implement Finance Laws in Morocco. The Finance law execution report should be provided to the court of auditors, parliament, and to the Government.

question: Elements
Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields:
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.
Provisions for data quality:
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
Provisions for openness, timing, and structure:
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Chapter 2 of the law (https://adala.justice.gov.ma/production/legislation/fr/Nouveautes/La%20loi%20organique%20n%C2%B0%20130-13%20relative%20%C3%A0%20la%20loi%20de%20finances.pdf ) establishes the requeirements for the budget presentation, it is not specific though. There is guidance of the Agency for the Development of Open Data, but this initiative is still in progress.

question: Extent
How comprehensive is the coverage of laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?
response: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national, and local government.

question: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g., defence sector.)
response: Finance law in Morocco does not include local government. The 2011 constitution of Morocco (Article 141) affirms the financial autonomy of local authorities and following the provisions of article 146 of the Constitution, each level of territorial collectivities (region, prefecture and province, municipality) now has its organic law which defines their respective rules of governance relating to the proper functioning of free administration. , controlling the management of funds and programs, evaluating actions and rendering accounts. The organic laws are 111-14, 112-14 and 113-14 respectively related to the regions, prefectures and provinces, and finally municipalities.

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Despite technical dysfunctions, we note that some work has been done to make available information about the budget and its execution.

The publication of the execution of economic and social plans from 2011 to 2020 represents a progression in the way in which the Ministry of Finance shares information about the state budget in Mozambique.

This research also found that the website of the Ministry of Economy and Finance has a section dedicated to explaining how the financial resources on the management of the COVID-19 pandemic are spent. The last report was published in July of this year.

Laws, regulations  assessed for this indicators provides basis for publishing data on public finances (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing. 
Annually a Budget Plan for the year is tabled and published in parliament and available online as in this year's case available here https://mof.gov.na/documents/35641/36583/Budget+Statement+2021_22.pdf/356d55a3-c7d5-fef1-941c-528b1baa787e as requirement by the State Finance Act.

As a requirement of the State finance act and the Constitution Article 126 (4), An appropriation Act for the budget, this was the case for 2020, which hence was published as well. A mid-term budget review also happens every year in October as per Hence there are existing laws  requiring collection and publication of information on government budget, spending, debt and borrowing.  However these amounts are not mentioned or referred to as data.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Nigeria's commitment to the Open Government Partnership (OGP) makes it possible to advance participatory budgeting and transparent Revenue Tax Reporting. The guidance provides the basis for collecting and publishing budget information as structured open data. The commitment ended in 2019.

Sources
(1)OGP, Citizen Participation in Budget Cycle (NG0001) 2017.
https://www.opengovpartnership.org/members/nigeria/commitments/NG0001/

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
There is actually a binding framework for the collection and publication of public finance data. 
- At the regional level, with the directives on the harmonized framework for public finances management of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS). This framework is made up of seven directives addressing various aspects of public financial governance. The most significant of these, which places specific emphasis on transparency and publication of data, is the directive on the code of transparency and good governance of public finances in the member states of the CEMAC zone.
- At the national level, two framework laws of July 11, 2018 address the issue of transparency, namely the law on the code of transparency and good governance in public finance management and the law on the financial regime of the State and other public entities

Sources :

(1) Cameroon General Tax Code 2021 : https://www.impots.cm/sites/default/files/documents/General%20Tax%20Code%202021.pdf

(2) Cameroon Finance Bill 2020 : https://www.cabri-sbo.org/en/documents/bill-on-the-finances-of-therepublic-of-cameroon-for-the-2020-financial-year

(3) https://www.crtv.cm/2021/06/parliament-national-assembly-adopts-2021-finance-ordinance-and-bill-to-promote-volunteering/

(4) 2021 - 2023 Budget Programming : https://www.minepat.gov.cm/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=612:2021-2023-budget-programming-spending-forecasts-are-being-refined&catid=25&Itemid=144&lang=en
 
(5) https://www.cabri-sbo.org/en/documents/budgetary-orientation-debateeconomic-programming-document-andmedium-term-budgetary-2021-2023

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
response:
