Law N0. 2018/011 of July 11, 2018 to establish the Code of Transparency and Good Governance in the Management of Public Finances in Cameroon enjoins the administration to take all necessary measures to publish information on public finances. To this end, Art 47 (3) of the Code specifies that "a specific text, taken before the beginning of the budgetary year publishes the timetable for the dissemination of information."

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Constitution of 18 January 1996 of the Republic of Cameroon stipulates that the Supreme Court is the highest jurisdiction in "judicial, administrative and auditing matters". It provides for the existence of a chamber of accounts within this court. According to Article 41 of the Constitution, "the Chamber of Accounts is competent to control and rule on public accounts and those of public and semi-public companies. It shall give a sovereign decision on the final decisions of the lower courts of audit.

The legal framework is laid down by the law of 21 April 2003 on the powers, organisation and functioning of the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court, which is an independent isntitution exercising control on governance and transparency in the management of public affairs. 

Sources:

(1) Cameroon Constitution of 1996 : https://www.assnat.cm/images/The_constitution.pdf

(2) Law of 21 April 2003 on the powers, organisation and functioning of the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court (available in French online )  http://www.cvuc-uccc.com/minat/textes/15.pdf

(3) http://bibliotheque.pssfp.net/index.php/institutions/institutions-nationales/chambre-des-comptes/1586-annual-report-2013/file

Additionnal information have been collected from interview with Mr Daniel EFANGON on August 2nd, project assistant in Public Finances Governance at the Ministry of Economy, Planning and Regional Development.

question: The availability of this data has been affected by government response to COVID-19.
1,2;Please briefly describe how COVID-19 affected the availability of this data.
response: Yes, of course, this framework has been the subject of an exceptional adjustment at the time of COVID-19. Indeed, the community directives on public finance management make the Court of Audit the financial watchdog par excellence. It is in this capacity that the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court of Cameroon has played and continues to play a major role in the transparency and accountability of the management of COVID funds. The fact that the Chamber of Accounts has been brought to the forefront is not a coincidence. From now on, it is the Chamber that will shed light on the governance of public finances through audits and various investigations, which it will also publish to ensure transparency in the governance of public finances.

question: The framework requires a verification process.
1;Please briefly explain the verification process used, and which parts of collected data the framework requires to be verified and which parts it does not.
response:
The control and verification of the regularity of financial transactions are carried out by control bodies, in particular the Court of Auditors (1). The Court of Auditors gives its opinion on the internal control system and the management control system, on the quality of the accounting procedures and accounts as well as on the annual performance reports. This opinion is accompanied by recommendations on desirable improvements. It is judicial control. It is supplemented by the control of the executive itself, ensured by the financial controllers. The latter report to the Minister in charge of finance and are appointed by him or at his initiative to the authorizing officers. They are responsible for the a priori controls of budgetary operations. They can give opinions on the quality of the management of authorizing officers and on performance. Finally, parliamentary control is ensured by the finance committees, which oversee the proper execution of finance laws during annual management
programs.

Sources: 
(1) https://www.courdescomptes.tg/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Loi-organique-n%C2%B02014-013-relative-au-Lois-de-Finances.pdf

response: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national, and local government.

question: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g., defence sector.)
response:
The defense sector has its own framework. This is the military programming law which sets the objectives of the defense effort and the programming associated with it for the period 2021-2025, as well as the conditions for their evaluation by parliament. Its purpose is to give Togo the means necessary for the defense of its national integrity, for the security of its population (1). 

Sources:

(1) http://jo.gouv.tg/sites/default/files/JO/JOS_24_12_2020%20-%2065%20E%20ANNEE%20N%C2%B047%20BIS.pdf#page=23

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The government budget and spending information (budget execution) are available but not as a structured data. The decree 2015 - 052 / PR on the budget nomenclature of the State (1) set the basis for publication of such data. Botswana has increased the availability of budget information by:

(1) Publishing the Enacted Budget online.

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
The Bank of Botswana collects information on monetary statistics under Section 20 of the Banking Act, which stipulates that "every bank shall not later than 21 days after the last day of each calendar month, submit to the central bank, in accordance with the generally accepted accounting practices in Botswana, in duplicate and in such form as the central bank may determine, a statement of its assets and liabilities established in such manner as the central bank may determine, together with such other information as the central bank may require in respect of its places of business in Botswana and abroad, as the case may be."

The Statistics Act 2009 authorizes the Statistician General to have access to records (administrative data, financial, geographic information etc.) from other statistics producing agencies.

The Banking Act provides for a mandatory report of the monthly balance sheets of the commercial banks within 21 days after the end of the reference month and imposes penalties in case of non-compliance. With regard to balance of payments statistics, the Banking Act does not specifically identify the compilation of balance of payments statistics as the BoB's responsibility. Therefore, the applicability of this provision depends on the informal intra-government agreement that the BoB assumes this responsibility.

Public Finance Management Act:

Section 45 (2) The Permanent Secretary shall publish an annual report on surcharges, losses
suffered by the Government and on any other matter provided for under this Part.


Section 55(3) The Minister shall, at every budget session of National Assembly, table a report of
the total abandonments and write-offs of public moneys and supplies for the financial year
ending.

As provided for in Section 4 (2) The Permanent Secretary shall publish an annual report on surcharges, losses suffered by the Government and on any other matter provided for under this Part. 


The law and the reform do not include any specific information on open data or data standards apart from citing the IFRS (1) 

(1) https://www.finance.gov.bw/images/LawRegulations/Public%20Finance%20Management.pdf
(2) https://dsbb.imf.org/egdds/country/BWA/category
(3) https://dsbb.imf.org/egdds/dqaf-base/country/BWA/category/BWXMOF00
(4) https://dsbb.imf.org/egdds/dqaf-base/country/BWA/category/BWXNSO00

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response: Performance information to guide service delivery is non-existent. The annual budget is developed according to economic and administrative classifications. There is very little evidence that performance information, such as performance targets, outputs and outcomes, are considered during the policy planning and budget allocation process. This has led to missed opportunities by not collecting and using critical performance data as evidence to guide policy and budgetary decisions especially when fiscal resources are limited.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Data on public finance is framed by a project of law presented to the parliament to be adopted before being promulgated by the President of the Republic each year. 
Any changes in the law regarding the annual budget are submitted to the adoption by the parliament before promulgation.
The parliament examines the disaggregated levels of revenues and expenses.
The law is issued at Journal Officiel of the Republic as a state law once it is adopted.

Source: Law 59-249 of December 23rd, 1959 related to public finances

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Under the guidance of Freedom of Information Act and the Budget Law(1) , the newly updated Regulation for the Implementation of Budget Law (2) in 2020 set much stronger requirements on publicly disclosing public finance data. It newly requires that government debts and procurements shoud be disclosed. It also requires disclosing much detailed data on public budget and spending.

However, there is no requirements set on how such information and data should be disclosed especially published as consumable data in a structured, machine-readable format.

barometer_region: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The main practical regulation of public finances is the Managing Public Money guidance, which sets out that all public sector organisations should adopt a publication scheme routinely offering information about the organisation's activities. They should also publish regular information about their plans, performance and use of public resources.[1]
The Local Government Transparency Code 2015 underwritten by the Local Government (Transparency Requirements) (England) Regulations 2015 mandates various elements of disclosure, including any expenditure over Â£500 and procurement credit cards.[2]
Â Sections 25 and 26 of the Local Audit and Accountability Act 2014 provide additional rights for persons to inspect a local authority's accounting records and supporting documentation, and to make copies of them. This is also used to drive proactive transparency.[3]
The direct oversight of the national budget falls on the Office for Budget Responsibility, which is also is tasked with producing various reports.[4] The OBR is a non-departmental public body, under the Budget Responsibility and National Audit Act 2011.[5] There is limited legal mandate to produce structured financial data but a lot is available from the OBR.



[1] Guidance Managing public money, 2021. https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/managing-public-money
[2] Local transparency guidance, The Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG), 2015. https://www.local.gov.uk/our-support/guidance-and-resources/data-and-transparency/local-transparency-guidance
[3] Local Audit and Accountability Act, 2014. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2014/2/contents/enacted
[4] Fiscal risks report â€“ July 2021, 2021. https://obr.uk/frr/fiscal-risks-report-july-2021
[5] Office for Budget Responsibility Legislation and related material, 2021. https://obr.uk/about-the-obr/legislation-and-related-material/

country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The UK has a sophisticated system for public finance and reviews to the government budget but not all the underlying data is available as structured open data.[1] There is much financial data available through the Office of National Statistics (ONS)[2] and some budget data is available through the Office of Budget Responsibilit[3]y, which also publishes the Economic and fiscal outlook with all underlying data.[4]  

The Public Expenditure Statistical Analyses (PESA) is the yearly publication of information on government spending. It brings together recent data that may be out of the budget, estimates for the latest year, and spending plans for the rest of the current spending review period.[5]

COVID has seen a "drop in the government's transparency on its spending" according to the Institute for Government.[6]


[1] Open Budget Survey 2019 Questionnaire United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, 2020. https://www.internationalbudget.org/sites/default/files/2020-05/united-kingdom-of-great-britain-and-northern-ireland-202002150030.pdf
[2] All data related to Public sector finances, UK: May 2021, 2021. https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/governmentpublicsectorandtaxes/publicsectorfinance/bulletins/publicsectorfinances/may2021/relateddata
[3] OBR Data Portal, 2021. https://obr.uk/data/
[4] Economic and fiscal outlook â€“ March 2021, 2021. https://obr.uk/efo/economic-and-fiscal-outlook-march-2021/
[5] Public Expenditure Statistical Analyses, 2020. https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/public-expenditure-statistical-analyses-2020
[6] Whitehall Monitor 2021, 2021. https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/publications/whitehall-monitor-2021

question: 1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL where administrative classifications are located.
response:
The Office for National Statistics (ONS), acting as an independent agency, prepares the UK's national accounts in accordance with the EU-legislated framework 'European System of Accounts 2010' (ESA10). ESA10 in turn is consistent with the System of National Accounts (SNA08), is an internationally agreed standard adopted by the United Nations and used globally. ESA10 and SNA08 provide a standardised international framework for preparing national accounts.

https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/876155/CBG_for_publication.pdf

question: 1,2;Please briefly describe how COVID-19 affected the availability of this data.
response: Due to significant pressures experienced by some departments responding to the COVID-19 pandemic, the administrative deadline for laying the 2019-20 departmental annual reports and accounts (ARAs) has been extended to 30th September 2020[footnote 1]. As a result, the 2019-20 outturn published in PESA may be subject to data quality issues due to the inability of some departments, taking advantage of the extension, to align outturn data accurately to their ARAs. It is likely that some departments will revise their outturn data to align fully with the publication of their ARAs later in the year. The public spending statistics (PSS) release, published on a quarterly basis, will reflect any later revisions made by departments for their 2019-20 outturn.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
In accordance with Article 9 (Publication of Fiscal Information) of the National Finance Act and Article 5 (Publication of Fiscal Information) of Enforcement Decree of the National Finance Act, the Government shall publish the budget, funds, settlement of accounts, the State bonds, loans, present value of the State-owned assets, consolidated fiscal balance, general government and public sector financial statistics, and other important matters prescribed by Presidential Decree concerning finances of the State and local governments, by appropriate means, including information communications media and printed materials, at least once a year in a transparent and easy-to-understand manner and the head of each central government agency shall disclose the current status of operation of its own revenue and expenditure budget on its web-site, and each fund managing entity shall disclose the current status of operation of the relevant fund on its website every day(1)(2). 
In the case of financial statistics, the Korea Institute of Public Finance supports publishing finance statistics prepared in accordance with the international statistics guidelines(GFSM and PSDS) every year(3).

Sources

(1) National Finance Act, Article 9, Act No. 17344, June 9, 2020.

question: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g., defence sector.)
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Ministry of Economy and Finance launched the 'Open Fiscal Data' site in 2015 to provide various financial-related data collected under the National Finance Act(1)(2)(4). Through this site, anyone can access financial statistics and original raw data related to national finance(2). Although the scope of application of the National Finance Act includes the state and local governments, in the case of local governments, the details shall follow the Local Finance Act. Therefore, detailed data on local finance can be provided through a separate system, 'Local Finance 365', an integrated local finance public disclosure system(3).

Sources

(1) National Finance Act, Article 9, Act No. 17344, June 9, 2020.
https://www.law.go.kr/ë²•ë ¹/êµ­ê°€ìž¬ì •ë²• (in Korean)
https://elaw.klri.re.kr/kor_service/lawView.do?hseq=54789&lang=ENG (in English)
(2) Open Fiscal Data, https://www.openfiscaldata.go.kr/portal/main.do 
(3) Local Finance 365, https://lofin.mois.go.kr/portal/main.do
(4) Korea Policy Briefing, National financial information and statistics at a glanceâ€¦ Operation of 'Open Finance' website, May 6, 2015. https://www.korea.kr/news/policyNewsView.do?newsId=148794781 (in Korean)

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Liberia's Public Finance Management Act requires the collection of information related to public debts and ensures that reports related to such debts are given to the president and legislation twice a year. The Act also requires that the national budget is made available to the public in draft form and after it is passed into law by the legislature.

The budget is published every year in keeping with the Public Finance Law. While the budget includes the expenditure or performance report for the previous year, the performance report does not report data for individual expenditures.

https://www.moci.gov.lr/doc/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act.pdf

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
The country's budget law requires that a budget performance report will be generated each year to reflect the previous year's spending. These spending reports are usually appended to the subsequent year's budget. The report contains information on government spending, debt, and borrowing.

Section 14 of the Public Finance Management Act also provides that the National Budget is published both in draft and final form. Section 32 of the Act also requires that data is collected on all public debts.
Source 
Public Finance Management Act, Section 14 and Section 32. 2009. https://www.moci.gov.lr/doc/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act.pdf

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Liberia's budgets are published publicly every year. Going back to 2014/2015 all of the country's budgets are available on the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning's website.

The Public Financial Management Act governs all matters related to the management of public finances in Liberia. The Act prescribes procedures for the budgeting process. The law, though, does not clearly provide guidelines on how data arising out of the country's financial management can be published.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The 1995 Constitution of the Republic of Uganda, Chapter 9, Articles 155-158, provide the legal basis for the preparation and approval of the national budget (1). The Budget Act (2) and the Public Finance Management Act 2015 is aligned to the Constitution of the Republic of Uganda. It is a comprehensive legal and regulatory framework that guides accountability systems for public resources entrusted to government of Uganda to administer on behalf of Ugandans. It includes the processes for the preparation, approval and management of a transparent, credible and predictable annual budget. The Public Finance Management Act 2015 requires the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development publishes several annual budget information such as background to the budget, the budget framework paper, the budget speech, the Ministerial policy statements, charter of fiscal responsibility, the draft estimates of revenue and expenditure, the public investment plan and the approved estimates for the financial year. It is important to note that this has been the practice for last 5 to 10 years where this information is made available in both hard copies - print media and softcopies - online - Ministry's website and Uganda budget information website(3).

Sources:
(1). The Constitution of the Republic of Uganda 1995
https://statehouse.go.ug/sites/default/files/attachments/Constitution_1995.pdf
(2) The Budget Act 2001
https://www.parliament.go.ug/cmis/browser?id=25616f73-e4cf-426b-b12e-c2e72b817b7c%3B1.0#:~:text=An%20Act%20To%20Provide%20for,for%20other%20Matters%20Connected%20therewith.&text=(1)%20This%20Act%20may%20be,st%20day%20of%20July%2C%202001
(3) The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
The Constitution of the Republic of Uganda 1995, Article 155 provides ground for publishing public finance information. Subsection 1 states that - The President shall cause to be prepared, submitted and laid before parliament in each financial year but in any case not later than the 15th day of June in the financial year, estimates of revenue and expenditure of the government for the next financial year (1). Additionally, the Budget Act 2001, section 4 on Macroeconomic plan and indicative framework, subsection 2 - states that the President shall, not later than the 1st day of April in each financial year and in preparation for the final submission, cause to be submitted and laid before parliament, indicative preliminary revenue and expenditure framework of Government for the next financial year (2) The Public Finance Management Act 2015, Part 3 focuses on government budget preparations, approval and management whereas Part 6 focuses on public debt, grants and guarantees. Section 13, subsection 9 states that the budget shall (c) supply detailed information on recent fiscal developments and forecasts for the period determined by the Minister in respect of - revenues, recurrent and capital expenditures, borrowing and debt servicing, contingent liabilities and any other information in respect of assets and liabilities that may be considered appropriate by the Minister. Section 42 focuses on the management of public debt. Subsection 4 requires Minister to publish data on public debt. It states that - The Minister shall cause to be published, through the appropriate means, the report on the management of the public debt, guarantees, and the other financial liabilities of Government (3).

Sources:

(1). The Constitution of the Republic of Uganda 1995
https://statehouse.go.ug/sites/default/files/attachments/Constitution_1995.pdf

(2). The Budget Act 2001
https://www.parliament.go.ug/cmis/browser?id=25616f73-e4cf-426b-b12e-c2e72b817b7c%3B1.0#:~:text=An%20Act%20To%20Provide%20for,for%20other%20Matters%20Connected%20therewith.&text=(1)%20This%20Act%20may%20be,st%20day%20of%20July%2C%202001.


(3). The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015, Subsection 12 under section 13 on annual budgets requires the Minister using appropriate means to publish budget information by 1st July (1). However, the legal framework does not mention if it should be open data.

Source:

(1) The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: Elements
Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields:
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015 talks about collecting and publishing public finance information as structured data. Specifically section 13 on annual budget and subsection 10  indicates that the annual budget shall consist of the financing estimates for the financial year to which the budget relates; the expenditure estimates for the preceding financial year, current financial year and proceeding financial year; a statement of the multi-year commitments to be made by government in the financial year; a statement of the tax expenditures of government, budgets of self accounting departments, commissions and organisations; and the grants to the local governments and any subventions for the financial year (1).

Source:

(1). The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015, section 16 focuses on - Report on expenditure commitments. Subsection 1 requires an accounting officer every three months to prepare and submit to the Secretary to the Treasury, an expenditure commitment report indicating the actual and forecast commitments and cash position of the vote; subsection 2 states that the Secretary to the Treasury shall using the report submitted in subsection 1 submit a consolidated expenditure commitment report of all the votes to the Minister, within thirty days after the end of the three months (1).

Sources:
(1) The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015, section 9 on Budget Framework Paper, subsection 4 states that the Budget Framework Paper shall be in the format prescribed in Schedule 3. The structured data in the Budget Framework Paper includes medium term macroeconomic forecast - the actual, estimated and projections covering the previous two years, the current financial year and the next five financial years and shall indicate respect of each financial year the following economic variables - the average and year end gross domestic product; the rate of inflation; the rate of employment and unemployment, the average and year end exchange rate; the interest rates and the money supply. Furthermore, shall include the medium-term fiscal framework and medium term fiscal forecast that shall cover the previous two financial years, the current financial year and the next 5 financial years and shall indicate in respect of each financial year, the following economic variables - a. the non-petroleum revenue of government in respect of - tax revenue, non-tax revenue and external grants for towards the annual budget and project grants; the petroleum revenue; the expenditure and net lending of government for  - the current expenditure, investment expenditure and net lending; the overall balance of government; the non-petroleum revenue balance and any errors and omissions  (1).

Sources:
(1). The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015, section 15 on commitment of approved budget, subsection 1 states that after approval of the annual budget by Parliament, the Secretary to Treasury shall issue the annual cashflow plan of Government, based on the procurement plans, work plans and recruitment plans approved by Parliament; subsection 2 states that the annual cashflow plan issued under subsection 1 shall be the basis for release of funds by the Accountant General to the Accounting Officers; and subsection 3 states that an Accounting Office shall commit the budget of a vote, based on the annual cashflow plan issued under this section (1).

Sources
(1) The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.
Provisions for data quality:
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015, Section 3 on interpretation refers to the Ministry responsible for finance and in this case is the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (1).

Sources:
(1). The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: The framework requires a verification process.
2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015, section 47 talks of the Internal Auditor General, subsection 1 - states that there is a designated by the Public Service, an Internal Auditor General who shall be subject to the terms and conditions governing Public Service; subsection 2 highlights the roles of the Internal Auditor General; section 48 states that every vote shall have an internal auditor and subsection 2 highlights his or her roles. Section 49, subsection 1 states that the Minister shall establish an audit committee for each sector of Government and audit committees for a number of votes in local governments (1).

Sources:
(1). The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: Provisions for openness, timing, and structure:
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
The Public Finance Management Act 2015, section 18 on reporting on fiscal performance, subsection 3 states that the Minister shall at least twice in a financial year, in consultation with all votes, review the fiscal progress towards achieving the annual goals and the expected outputs defined in annual budget; subsection 4 states that the consultation required in subsection 3 shall identify the corrective measures, including the adjustments to the medium-term expenditure frameworks as well as the requirement for any supplementary budgets or any reallocations to be undertaken (1).

Sources:
(1). The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
Extent
How comprehensive is the coverage of laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?
response: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national, and local government.

question: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g., defence sector.)
response:
The Public Finance Management Act, 2015 applies across the whole public sector including national and local government. However, Section 24 looks at classified expenditure. subsection 1 - states that the money appropriated for classified expenditure shall only be used for defence and national security purposes. subsection 3 states that - to ensure the confidentiality of defence and national security matters, a budget for classified expenditure shall be presented as a single line item (1).

Source:
(1) The Public Finance Management Act 2015
https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act%202015.pdf

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (MoFPED) is running a budget data portal on their website. This website provides access to official government budget datasets in both machine-readable and non-machine readable formats that can be accessed freely by the public online. The website also provides some interactive graphics to illustrate the numbers and data downloads for more in-depth analysis. The datasets available cover a range of years from 2013 to date and is available in machine-readable format and freely accessible online (1). Furthermore, despite the existence of COVID-19, the Ministry has been able to continuously publish the budget data online (budget portal and social media pages) including the income and expenditures on COVID-19 pandemic in Uganda (2). All the datasets are published in English and cover all the government Ministries, Departments and Agencies at the national and local government levels. It is also important to note that on the budget data portal, there is no indication under which the data is licensed.

Source
(1) Uganda Budget Information website
http://budget.go.ug/dataportal

(2) COVID-19 Budget Allocations https://budget.go.ug/sites/default/files/National%20Budget%20docs/COVID%20Allocations%2019_20%20and%2020_21%20_updated.pdf

Supplementary Budget Expenditure on Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development Facebook page
https://www.facebook.com/MofpedUganda/photos/pcb.3583859485046941/3583859121713644

Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development Facebook page with COVID-19 releases
https://www.facebook.com/MofpedUganda/photos/pcb.3583859485046941/3583859371713619

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Budget transparency (1) is a requirement of the countries of the West African Monetary Union. Local (2) finances are also affected by budget transparency in the West African monetary union. An annual report from the West African Monetary Union takes stock of economic developments. Here is an example of the union's annual report (3). Benin is a good student when it comes to budget transparency. The finance law is passed on the right date with the production of all the framework and execution documents for the general state budget. Information on external resource mobilization and debt is also available. Regular arbitration is made with the financial technical partners to guarantee the mobilization of pledges of resources and the efficient consumption of credits and grants. Before the vote on the finance law for each year n + 1, the draft of the general state budget is often made available for criticism by civil society (4) organizations interested in governance. These criticisms shed light on the budget debate in the National Assembly and may induce corrections before the vote. Budget guidelines are specific from one year to the next. They take into account the challenges of the moment.

Sources:
(1) http://www.uemoa.int/sites/default/files/bibliotheque/directive_01_2009_cm_uemoa.pdf
(2) http://www.uemoa.int/sites/default/files/bibliotheque/directive_01_2011_cm_uemoa.pdf
(3) http://www.uemoa.int/sites/default/files/bibliotheque/uemoa_rapport_annuel_sur_le_fonctionnement_de_l-union_2020.pdf
(4) https://socialwatch.bj/?p=1656

It is the law on the fight against corruption which imposed on the state the publication of the finance law (1) and the general budget of the state. Accountability is regularly requested by civil society organizations on the basis of the requirements of the law (2).
Sources :

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
In Malawi, the Public Finance Management Act(2003), provide for publication of financial information as regards public funds. Section 13 and section 83 of the PFMA requires the Secretary to the Treasury to prepare a consolidated financial statement.

However, there is no specific law, or regulations that places a demand on the Secretary to the Treasury to provide information to the public per se. For example monthly, quarterly or whenever someone asks for it.

Accordingly, to law, financial information can be officially made public after audited and certified by the Auditor General. This is a limitation of the legal framework regarding access to public financial information.

The Access to Information Act, can be used to access specific and relevant information.

Sources
Public Finance Management Act (2003)
https://www.icam.mw/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Public-Finance-Management-Act-2003.pdf

Public Audit Act https://malawilii.org/mw/legislation/act/2003/6

Access to Information Act https://malawilii.org/mw/legislation/act/2017/13

The Ministries, Departments and Government Agencies are also required to provide accurate information to the Ministry of Finance.

On the hand from the public finance management view, though there is no specific provision, the officials involved in the compilation of the budget or any statistics, must act proffessionally and ensure that the information provided is as accurate as possible.

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Budget and spending information is generally available. The information is partially available on line and off line( visiting a government office). Part of the budget and spending information can be found on the Ministry of Finance website. The chalenge is that the information available on the line may not be comprehensive enough and is not updated regularly. Since there is no legal instrument that requires the Treasury to publish the information. The data available on the website is usually unaudited information, since only after the Auditor General has certified the information or transactions,then the information can be considered official. This aspect of the process is not done to update the records in case, the Auditor General has made some corrections.

Any relevant data can be obtained by invoking the Access to Information Act. The catch word is that "relevant data", as the right to access information is not absolute, there are some conditions which should be fulfilled first before the data could be released.

All in all, the budget and spending information is available, but not publically available on line in a comprehensive manner and up todate. No law or regulations compels the authorities to update or publish information to the general public.



Sources

Annual Economic Report https://www.finance.gov.mw/index.php/our-documents/annual-economic-reports


Budget Statements https://www.finance.gov.mw/index.php/our-documents/budget-statements

Access to Information Act
https://malawilii.org/mw/legislation/act/2017/13.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Section 20, subsection 2c of The Public Financial Management Act 2016 only generally requires public institutions to furnish the public with information on fiscal objectives, policies, data, and risks(1). It states:  Notwithstanding the generality of subsection 1, any
person, institution, or agency referred to under subsection 1, shall be guided by the following principles of responsible financial managementâ€“
provide timely, reliable, and adequate information to the public on fiscal objectives, policies, data, and risks to ensure transparency in the budgetary and financial management of the general government and public enterprises;
Section 33, subsection 3 further stipulates that the national budget be gazetted and then published on the website of the Ministry of Finance(2).
However, these provisions do not specifically require that the data be structured nor do they provide guidelines on the type and quality of data to publish. In the same vein, the Right to Access Information Act is also limited.

Sources:
(1) Public Financial Management Act, Section 20, Subsection 2c, 2016, http://www.sierra-leone.org/Laws/2016-13.pdf
(2) Public Financial Management Act, Section 33, Subsection 3, 2016, http://www.sierra-leone.org/Laws/2016-13.pdf


###Reference
(1) Interview with Alfred Demby, Deputy Director in the Public Financial Management Unit of the Ministry of Finance

provide timely, reliable, and adequate information to the public on fiscal objectives, policies, data, and risks to ensure transparency in the budgetary and financial management of the general government and public enterprises;
Section 33  subsection 3 stipulates that the budget be gazetted and then published on the website of the Ministry of Finance (2).

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
Even though Section 20(2)(c) and Section 33(3) of The Public Financial Management Act 2016 generally require public institutions to furnish the public with budget and expenditure information(1), the budget published on the website of the Ministry of Finance is only available as an unstructured Word document. The data provided is quite comprehensive, however, and includes information on fiscal policy, objectives, expenditures, and projections.

Source:
(1) The Public Financial Management Act, Section 33, subsection 3, 2016, http://www.sierra-leone.org/Laws/2016-13.pdf

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
There are several regulations on public finance governing the collection and publication of structured data. The Budget Code of the Russian Federation (1) defines the principle of transparency (openness). In Russia, there is a state information system "Electronic Budget", which has an open part "The Unified Portal of the Budget System" (2). The electronic budget is regulated by a number of regulatory legal acts posted on the website of the Ministry of Finance of Russia (3). The Federal Law (No. 8-FZ, entered into force on February 9, 2009) "On providing access to information on the activities of state bodies and local self-government bodies" (4) establishes an obligation for state bodies of the federal, regional and municipal levels to publish information on the use of budget funds by a state body, its territorial bodies, local self-government bodies, subordinate organizations. The list of the open financial data published by regional and municipal financial government agencies on the Electronic Budget Portal is regulated by the Order of the Ministry of Finance of Russia No 243n "On the Composition and Procedure for Fosting and Providing Information on a Single Portal of the Budgetary System of the Russian Federation" (5).

##Sources
[1] http://www.consultant.ru/document/cons_doc_LAW_19702/
[2] https://budget.gov.ru/
[3] https://minfin.gov.ru/ru/perfomance/ebudget/npa/
[4] https://rg.ru/2009/02/13/dostup-dok.html
[5] http://www.consultant.ru/document/cons_doc_LAW_216452/

[The Federal Law (No. 8-FZ, entered into force on February 9, 2009) "On providing access to information on the activities of state bodies and local self-government bodies"](https://rg.ru/2009/02/13/dostup-dok.html)

[The Order of the Ministry of Finance of Russia No 243n "On the Composition and Procedure for Fosting and Providing Information on a Single Portal of the Budgetary System of the Russian Federation"](http://www.consultant.ru/document/cons_doc_LAW_216452/)

response: There are several regulations on public finance. In Russia, there is a state information system "Electronic Budget", which has an open part "The Unified Portal of the Budget System" (budget.gov.ru). The electronic budget is regulated by a number of regulatory legal acts posted on the website of the Ministry of Finance of Russia (https://minfin.gov.ru/ru/perfomance/ebudget/npa/). The Federal Law (No. 8-FZ, entered into force on February 9, 2009) "On providing access to information on the activities of state bodies and local self-government bodies" (https://rg.ru/2009/02/13/dostup-dok.html) establishes an obligation for state bodies of the federal, regional and municipal levels to publish information on the use of budget funds by a state body, its territorial bodies, local self-government bodies, subordinate organizations. The list of the open financial data published by regional and municipal financial government agencies on the Electronic Budget Portal is regulated by the Order of the Ministry of Finance of Russia No 243n "On the Composition and Procedure for Fosting and Providing Information on a Single Portal of the Budgetary System of the Russian Federation" (http://www.consultant.ru/document/cons_doc_LAW_216452/).

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The information about detailed data on government spending is published on the portal of the Electronic budget (1). It is the machine-readable data from the Federal Treasure. Data has the same detailing as a national budget and they are updated regularly. On this dataset, user can know, how much the government agencies spend on the expenditure directions (4-5 classifiers), but there is no information about the recipients of this money.

The Federal Treasure also has the section "Execution of Budgets" (2) on its website. Users can find data about the execution of federal budget (operational, monthly, quarterly, annual data), executions of regional budgets (monthly, annual data), executions of extra-budgetary funds.

##Sources

question: 0,1,2,3;Please, briefly explain your answer.
response:
Budget for State Owned Enterprises (SOEs) is sensitive in nature because most of the SOEs are overburdened with mounting
cumulative losses. It has been a matter of great controversy and concern among experts and donors. However, the government cannot undertake
privatization and deregulation mainly because of political pressure and loss of employment. Therefore, the government publishes a summary of their
financial position in a separate report as a part of transparency in spending money for them and place it with the EBP.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Law on Public Finance does not require government bodies to publish any budget information. However, the Cambodian government has committed itself to increase budget transparency (as part of the implementation of Phase 3 of its Public Financial Management Reform Program and improved its score in the Open Budget Survey from 8 (in 2015) to 32 (in 2019) by publishing more information about its revenue and expenditure. Sub-national legislation requires that provinces, municipalities, districts and municipalities at annual public forums provide citizens with information about the allocation of development funds and the implementation of development plans, which presumably include the expenditure, although the language of the relevant sections is a bit vague (thus taking the form of guidance rather than a requirement). 
Sources:
(1) International Budget Partnership. Open Budget Survey Cambodia 2019. https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/cambodia
(2) Public Financial Management Reform Programme. Ministry of Economy and Finance, Royal Government of Cambodia. https://www.pfm.gov.kh/index.php/en/about-pfm-en
(3) Commune Administration Law. Cambodia. http://huskyandpartners.com/images///Law%20Library/Administrative%20Law/20180825-Law%20on%20Commune-Sangkat%20Administrative%20Management_2001_En.pdf
(4) Law on the Administrative Management of Capital, Provinces, Municipalities and Districts. Cambodia. https://seaknowledgebank.net/e-library/cambodia-law-administrative-management-capital-provinces-municipalities-districts

[Law on Administrative Management of Capital, Provinces, Municipalities and Districts](https://seaknowledgebank.net/e-library/cambodia-law-administrative-management-capital-provinces-municipalities-districts)

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act, 2003 and the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Rules, 2004 provide the legal framework and require disclosures by the Central Government at the time of presentation of annual financial statement, demands for grants and other statements. The rules empower the Comptroller and Auditor General of India to conduct audits and ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data. 

Sources:
Ministry of Finance.(2003). The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act.

Ministry of Finance.(2004). Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Rules.

https://www.dea.gov.in/sites/default/files/FRBM%20Act%202003%20and%20FRBM%20Rules%202004.pdf
[The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act, 2003](http://archive.today/2021.08.15-155838/https://legislative.gov.in/sites/default/files/A2003-39.pdf)
[Constitutional Provisions of Comptroller and Auditor-General of India](http://archive.today/2021.08.15-160440/https://cag.gov.in/en/page-constitutional-provisions)

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
There are regulations requiring collection or publication of data on public finances. 

Regulations assessed are: 
(1) Law No. 14/2018 article 9 paragraph 2 on Freedom of Information Act constitutes that information on public financial report is required to be made available to public bodies periodically, at least once every six months 

(2) Presidential Regulation no.39/2019 on One Data Indonesia regulates collection and publication of public finance data
 
(3) Finance Minister Decree No.878/KMK.01/2019 on Data Governance in the Ministry of Finance

[Presidential Regulation No.39/2019 on One Data Indonesia (in Bahasa Indonesia)](https://2021-files.globaldatabarometer.org/192/0kaTB20-Perpres%20Nomor%2039%20Tahun%202019_Satu%20Data%20Indonesia.pdf)
[Finance Minister Decree No.878/KMK.01/2019 on Data Governance in the Ministry of Finance](https://archive.ph/wip/YhHji)

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response: Law No. 14/2018 article 9 paragraph 2 on Freedom of Information Act constitutes that information on public financial report is required to be made available to public bodies periodically (at least once every six months). The Presidential Regulation no.39/2019 on One Data Indonesia also regulates collection and publication of public finance data, further regulated under Finance Minister Decree No.878/KMK.01/2019 on Data Governance in the Ministry of Finance.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
Regulations/guidelines requiring collection or publication of public finances are as follows :
i) 'General Circular No.1 Year 2015 - Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiatives' which consists of 'Guidelines on the Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiative' as Appendix 1. This circular was issued on 30th September 2015 by the Chief Secretary to the Government of Malaysia which aims to provide guidelines on the implementation of open data in public sector. URL: https://www.data.gov.my/p/pekeliling-data-terbuka

Furthermore, the guidelines aim to provide guidance to public sector agencies in implementing the public sector open data initiatives towards sharing of government data, quality improvement and transparency of service delivery as well as to encourage economic growth of the country through innovations.
MAMPU (central agency under Prime Minister's Department) as the entrusted agency to spearhead the implementation of data driven initiatives has developed open data & big data analytics programs based on this circular, Public Sector ICT Strategic Plan Year 2016-2020 and Public Sector Digitalization Plan Year 2021-2025. These data driven programs consist of strategies and activities such as roadshows, engagement, training etc and action plans.

ii) 'Pekeliling Kemajuan Pentadbiran Awam Bil.2 Tahun 2015 - Pengurusan Laman Web Agensi Sektor Sektor Awam (Public Administration Development Circular No.2 Year 2015 - Management of Public Sector Agency Website)' which consist of 'Guidelines on the Management of the Public Sector Agency Website' as Appendix 1. URL: https://www.mampu.gov.my/en/circulars/category/182-2018

The coverage of the above circular (guidelines) are national level. However, over time, the content of the circular has room for improvement.
[General Circular No.1 Year 2015 - Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiatives](https://www.data.gov.my/p/pekeliling-data-terbuka)

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
i) 'General Circular No.1 Year 2015 - Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiatives' which consists of 'Guidelines on the Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiative' as Appendix 1. This circular was issued on 30th September 2015 by the Chief Secretary to the Government of Malaysia which aims to provide guidelines on the implementation of open data in public sector. Furthermore, the guidelines aim to provide guidance to public sector agencies in implementing the public sector open data initiatives toward sharing of government data, quality improvement and transparency of service delivery as well as to encourage economic growth of the country through innovations.
MAMPU (central agency under Prime Minister's Department) as the entrusted agency to spearhead the implementation of data driven initiatives has developed open data & big data analytics programs based on this circular, Public Sector ICT Strategic Plan Year 2016-2020 and Public Sector Digitalization Plan Year 2021-2025. These data driven programs consist of strategies and activities such as roadshows, engagement, training etc and action plans.
ii) 'Pekeliling Kemajuan Pentadbiran Awam Bil.2 Tahun 2015 - Pengurusan Laman Web Agensi Sektor Sektor Awam (Public Administration Development Circular No.2 Year 2015 - Management of Public Sector Agency Website)' which consists of 'Guidelines on the Management of the Public Sector Agency Website' as Appendix 1.

question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
response: Requirements to publish this information as open data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
Elements
Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields:
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Neither circular states that summary reports must be provided as structured data. However, data stewards are encouraged to publish summary reports which are open to the public as open data during trainings, roadshows and engagement programs. Moreover, publishing summary reports are from structured data (excel etc).

question: Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Both circulars did not mention that summary reports must be provided as structured data. However, data stewards are encouraged to publish expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification which are open to public as open data during trainings, roadshows and engagement programs. Moreover, publishing expenditure information is from structured data (excel etc).

question: The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Both circulars did not mention that executive budget proposal information should be provided as structured data. However, data stewards are encouraged to publish summary reports which are open to public as open data during trainings, roadshows and engagement programs. Moreover, publishing executive budget proposal is from structured data (excel etc).

question: The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Both circulars did not mention that approved or enacted budget should be provided as structured data. However, data stewards are encouraged to publish approved or enacted budget which are open to public as open data during trainings, roadshows and engagement programs. Moreover, publishing approved or enacted budget is from structured data (excel etc).

question: The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Both circulars did not mention that in-year reports should be provided as structured data. However, data stewards are encouraged to publish in-year reports which are open to public as open data during trainings, roadshows and engagement programs. Moreover, in-year reports are from structured data (excel etc).

question: The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Both circulars did not mention that year-end reports should be provided as structured data. However, data stewards are encouraged to publish year-end reports which are open to public as open data during trainings, roadshows and engagement programs. Moreover, year-end reports are from structured data (excel etc).

question: Provisions for data quality:
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response: The 'General Circular No.1 Year 2015 - Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiatives' which consists of 'Guidelines on the Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiative', guidance to ensure accurate and timely collection and publication of data is under "Principles of Public Sector Open Data", 6 (i) and (iii), page 3 of the guidelines.

question: The framework requires a verification process.
2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response: The 'General Circular No.1 Year 2015 - Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiatives' which consists of 'Guidelines on the Implementation of the Public Sector Open Data Initiative' indicates that the implementation of agency open data shall be based on the governance and activities agreed by the Heads of Departments in accordance to the checklist in Appendix C: Checklist for the Implementation of Agency Open Data of the guidelines. The checklist comprises of activities such as to establish governance structure to implement the tasks/activities relating to agency open data, develop the agency open data implementation plan, identify agency datasets that may be uploaded or linked to the Public Sector Open Data Portal (www.data.gov.my), review/verify the implementation of the open data initiative and assess its usage.

question: Provisions for openness, timing, and structure:
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Timely/regularly updated and up-to-date website content are under the second circular namely 'Pekeliling Kemajuan Pentadbiran Awam Bil.2 Tahun 2015 - Pengurusan Laman Web Agensi Sektor Sektor Awam (Public Administration Development Circular No.2 Year 2015 - Management of Public Sector Agency Website)' which consists of 'Guidelines on the Management of the Public Sector Agency Website' as Appendix 1.
Regularly updated is under section "Pembangunan Laman Web Agensi Sektor Awam (Development of Public Sector Agency Website)", 5 (ii), (j), (k); and 5 (iii)(d). Moreover, timely and up-to-date website content is also elaborated under section "Pengukuran Prestasi Penyampaian Maklumat dan Perkhidmatan (Information and Service Delivery Performance Measurement", 11 (iv); "Tadbir Urus Laman Web Agensi Sektor Awam (Public Sector Agency Website Governance)", 15 (i)(a)(4) and 15(iii) which indicates that among the Terms of Reference for Agency Website Management Working Committee is to ensure that website content is up-to-date.

question: The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response: Both circulars did not mention that year-end reports should be provided as structured data. However, data stewards are encouraged to publish year-end reports which are open to the public as open data during trainings, roadshows and engagement programs. Moreover, year-end reports are from structured data (excel etc).

question: Extent
How comprehensive is the coverage of laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?
response: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national, and local government.

question: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g., defence sector.)
response: The circular (guidelines) is national level and applies across the whole public sector at national, sub-national and local government without exception. Nevertheless, the content of the circular is not comprehensive and has the opportunity to be enhanced and improved.

question: Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
1,2;If budget and spending data can be found in multiple datasets, please provide the URL where functional classifications are located.
response:
i) http://treasury.gov.my/arkib/perbelanjaan/2020/ringkasan_angggaran_belanja_persekutuan_2020.pdf
ii) https://www.data.gov.my/data/ms_MY/dataset/perangkaan-kewangan-kerajaan-persekutuan-2006-1015/resource/ebdb98b6-d848-45ed-bc47-dc3d9e861495

The expenditures are classified into these sectors (functions):
1. General Administration (General Services, Foreign Services, refunds and reimbursements, Repairs and Renovation)
2. Economy (Agriculture and Rural Development, Mining Development, Trade and Industry, Transport, Communication, Energy and Public Facilities,
Research and Development, Finance, and Environment)
3. Social (Education and Training, Health and Population, Information, Housing, Culture Youth and Sports, Local Councils, Community Development,
National Unity and Indigenous People, Land Purchase, Rural Development)
4. Security (Defense and Domestic Security)
5. Other Sectors (e.g. Pensions, Bonuses, Loan Payments)
6. Contingency Reserves

These sectors are not identical to COFOG, but the categories can be mapped to it.

question: Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.

'Project code' for development expenditure and 'Vot number/code' for operating expenditure. These two codes/identifiers are the most disaggregated level of economic classification available. Moreover, monitoring of projects (by project code) is done by every ministry and reported to a dedicated central agency namely the Economic Planning Unit and Implementation Coordination Unit (Prime Minister's Department) for development budget projects. Whereas Ministry of Finance is monitoring operating expenditure such as emoluments, supplies & services, assets, maintenance, training etc. URL: 
i) https://www.data.gov.my/data/ms_MY/dataset/senarai-projek-pembangunan-rancangan-malaysia-kesebelas-rmke-11-kementerian-kewangan-malaysia/resource/27ae0972-b23f-4b5c-bf3e-18a697ff4f14

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The Constitution of Nepal requires the collection and publication of data on public finances [1] by all tires of government; the national, provincial, and local governments of Nepal. It has a dedicated section defining State Legislative Procedures, State Financial Procedures, Local Financial Procedures, Auditor General, etc. Although, the publication of the data in the structured form is not mentioned in the law. The Right to Information Act 2007 [2] guarantees citizens access to public information, but for that, the citizen has to submit the request demanding the information. the stakeholder engagement strategy [3] document produced by the Office of Auditor General [4] has provided space for Citizen Participatory Audit and Financial Ordinance 2078 [5] published by the Ministry of Finance [6] guarantees the information to be updated. As per the country report of the Open Budget Survey 2019 [7], Nepal has improved budget transparency but the room for participation is still there [8].

[1] Nepal Constitution 2072: https://www.wipo.int/edocs/lexdocs/laws/en/np/np029en.pdf
[2] Right to Information Act 2007: https://nic.gov.np/files/new_files/rti-act-2007.pdf
[3] Stakeholders Engagement Strategy: https://oagnep.gov.np/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/SES-Strategy-Final.pdf
[4] Office of Auditor General: https://oag.gov.np/
[5] Financial Ordinance 2078: https://www.mof.gov.np/uploads/document/file/1628139903_%E0%A4%86%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%A5%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%95%20%E0%A4%90%E0%A4%A8,%20%E0%A5%A8%E0%A5%A6%E0%A5%AD%E0%A5%AE%20(%E0%A4%85%E0%A4%A7%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A6%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%B6).pdf
[6] Ministry of Finance: https://www.mof.gov.np
[7] Open Budget Survey 2019 - Nepal: https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/nepal
[8] Nepal improves budget transparency; still more room for participation: http://freedomforum.org.np/budget-transparency/

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
The Constitution of Nepal requires the collection and publication of data on public finances. The following part and articles of the Nepal Constitution have specific provisions on fiscal management and transparency/accountability and arrangements.
- Directive Principles (page 28)
- Distribution of sources of revenue (page 47)
- Article 110 (2,3 and 4) and 111: Part 9 and 0 (page 76-86)
- Part 15, State Legislative Procedures (page 131-134)
- Part 16, State Financial Procedures (page 135 -138)
- Part 19, Local Financial Procedure (page 148 -149)
- Part 22, Auditor General (page 158-160)
The Right to Information Act 2007 guarantees citizen access to public information. Likewise, the stakeholder engagement strategy document produced by the Office of Auditor General has provided space for Citizen Participatory Audit.

question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
response: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The Ministry of Finance, each individual ministry, and government institutions are responsible for preparing the yearly budget in Nepal. The Ministry of Finance prepares and publishes the Budget Details Red Book [1] which consists of the national level budget details, whereas the Financial Comptroller General Office (FCGO) [2] tracks the spending data. The consolidated financial statements [3] consist of the details of the spending data and we can also use the daily budgetary analysis tool [4] to explore the daily revenue and expenditure details of the national government. The Office of Auditor General [5] audits the government spending data each year. The audit reports of the spending by local levels [6], provincial levels [7], state-owned enterprises [8], and others are available at the office of the auditor general website. In parliament, the Public Accounts Committee oversees spending irregularities. Most of the datasets are available in a non-machine-readable format and are not open licensed.

[1] Budget Details Red Book: https://www.mof.gov.np/site/publication-category/28
[2] Financial Comptroller General Office website: https://www.fcgo.gov.np/
[3] Consolidated Financial Statements: https://www.fcgo.gov.np/reporttype/1
[4] Daily Budgetary Analysis Tool: https://www.fcgo.gov.np/daily-budgetary-analysis
[5] Office of Auditor General website: https://oag.gov.np/
[6] Spending audits at local levels: https://oag.gov.np/local-level/report/en
[7] Spending audits at provincial levels: https://oag.gov.np/menu-category/962/en
[8] Spending audits of state-owned enterprises: https://oag.gov.np/menu-category/934/en

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The main guiding policy when it comes to Philippine Public Finance would be the highest law of the land itself -- the 1987 Philippine Constitution, specifically Sections 24 and 25. The land's main agency for public finance -- the Department of Budget and Management -- meanwhile, gets its mandate from an ancient policy (Executive Order No. 25, s. 1936).

Sources:

https://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/constitutions/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines-article-vi/

https://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/1936/04/25/executive-order-no-25-s-1936/

Source: https://dbm.gov.ph/index.php/about-us/mandate

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

response: It is included in several parts of the 1987 Philippine Constitution specifically Sections 24 and 25, as well as in the Administrative Code of 1987. When it comes to annual national budgets, provisions on publication are included in the law to pass the budget itself.
