question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The laws and regulations assessed mention the collection and publication of information on public finances, however they do not require the information to be published as structured / open data.

Sources:
(1) The Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act, No. 3 of 2003. https://www.srilankalaw.lk/YearWisePdf/2003/FISCAL_MANAGEMENT_(RESPONSIBILITY)_ACT,_No._3_OF_2003.pdf
(2) Municipal Council Ordinance of 1947. https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/municipal-councils-4/ 
(3) Pradeshiya Sabha Act of 1987. https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/pradeshiya-sabhas-3/
(4) National Audit Act, No. 19 of 2018. http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/public_news_agdsl/2018_news/Natinal_Audit_Act/Nationa-Audot-Act_E.pdf
(5) Urban Councils Ordinance of 1939. https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/urban-councils-3/

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
The Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act, No. 3 of 2003 of Sri Lanka provides the legal basis for the collection and publication of this information: "An act to ensure that the financial strategy of the. Government is based on principles of responsible fiscal management ; to facilitate public scrutiny of fiscal policy and performance ; and to provide for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto." 
(https://www.srilankalaw.lk/YearWisePdf/2003/FISCAL_MANAGEMENT_(RESPONSIBILITY)_ACT,_No._3_OF_2003.pdf). 

For local government public finance, the Municipal Council Ordinance of 1947 (https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/municipal-councils-4/), the Urban Councils Ordinance of 1939 (https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/urban-councils-3/)  and the Pradeshiya Sabha Act of 1987 (https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/pradeshiya-sabhas-3/)  contain relevant provisions. "Pradeshiya Sabha" is a type of local government authority in Sri Lanka.

question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
response: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
response:
Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act, No. 3 of 2003: https://www.srilankalaw.lk/YearWisePdf/2003/FISCAL_MANAGEMENT_(RESPONSIBILITY)_ACT,_No._3_OF_2003.pdf
Section 10. (1) "The Minister shall cause to be released to the public, in respect of every year, a Mid-Year Fiscal Position Report, by the last day of the month of June of the relevant year or the lapse of six months from the date of the passing of the Appropriation Act, whichever is later."
Section 13.(1) "The Minister shall cause to be released to the public, in respect of each financial year, a Final Budget Position Report, not later than five months from the end of the financial year."
Section 16. (1) "The Secretary to the Ministry of the Minister, shall within three weeks of the publication our Proclamation or Order requiring the holding of a general election for the election of members of Parliament, cause to be released to the public a Pre-election Budgetary Position Report containing information on the fiscal position of the country."   

Municipal Council Ordinance of 1947: https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/municipal-councils-4/
Section 212: "Every budget of a Municipal Council shall- 
(a) be circulated among the Councillors at least seven days prior to the date referred to in section 211; and 
(b) be open to inspection at the Municipal office or at such other place as the Mayor may determine, for seven days prior to the said date and notice thereof shall be given by the Mayor in the Gazette and in two or more of the newspapers circulating within the Municipality."

Urban Councils Ordinance of 1939: https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/urban-councils-3/ 
Section 176. (3): "The book or books of accounts of an Urban Council shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of the members of the Council, and every householder resident within the town administered by the Council, and any member of the Council or any such householder may take copies of or extracts from such book or books free of all charges."
Section 201. "It shall be the duty of the Commissioner to prepare and publish annually an administration report and a review of the work and expenditure of the Urban Councils in Sri Lanka. Every such report and review shall be laid before Parliament, and may be published in such manner as the Commissioner may determine." 

Pradeshiya Sabha Act of 1987: https://www.lawnet.gov.lk/pradeshiya-sabhas-3/
Section 171. "The administration by a Pradeshiya Sabha of the Pradeshiya Sat-ha Fund and of the property vested in, or used or occupied by, the Pradeshiya Sabha, shall be further subject to such rules of procedure as may be made under this section for prescribing"
(d) "the form in which books of accounts shall be pre pared and kept by a Pradeshiya Sabha ;
(e) the form of the periodical statements of accounts which shall be prepared by a Pradeshiya Sabha ; 
(f) the manner in which, the intervals at which, and the persons by whom the books, accounts, documents and other records of a Pradeshiya Sabha, the work of construction, maintenance or repair undertaken or executed by a Pradeshiya Sabha, and the lands and buildings vested in or used or occupied by a Pradeshiya Sabha shall be inspected ; and 
(g) the mode of giving notice within the limits of a Pradeshiya Sabha of the financial proposals of a Pradeshiya Sabha, and of publishing the periodical statements of accounts."

2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act, No. 3 of 2003:
Section 22. (1): "The Secretary to the Ministry of the Minister in charge of the subject of Finance, may in writing, request any Ministry, Department, Public Corporation or Company in which the Government owns shares, to furnish to him or her, such information as is necessary for the preparation of the Statement referred to in section 4 and the Reports referred to in sections 7, 10, 13 and 16."

Urban Councils Act of 1939
Section 180 (1): "The Chairman of every Urban Council shall, as soon as may be after the close of each financial year, prepare a detailed report of the administration of the Council during such financial year, with a statement showing the nature and amount of receipts and disbursements on account of the local fund during that year." This is done as prescribed by the Commissioner. 

Pradeshiya Sabha Act of 1987: 
Section 19. (4): "The Minister [in charge of local government] or the Commissioner [of the Pradeshiya Sabha] may, from time to time, direct the Sabha in writing to furnish him in such form as he may require, returns, accounts and other information with respect to the business of such enterprise, and the Sabha shall carry out recovery such direction."

question: The framework requires a verification process.
2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response:
The National Audit Act of 2018 of Sri Lanka is "An act to provide for the powers, duties and functions of the audit service commission; the establishment of the office of the National Audit Office and the Sri Lanka State Audit Service; to specify the role of the Auditor General over public finance and to make provision for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto."
Part I, Section 3(2): "The scope of an audit carried out by the Auditor General includes examining the accounts, finances, financial position and prudent management of public finance and properties of auditee entities."
Part II, Section 6(3). "Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1) of section 3, the Minister in charge of any public corporation, business or other undertaking vested in the Government under any written law and companies registered or deemed to be registered under the Companies Act, No. 7 of 2007 in which the Government or a public corporation or a local authority holds fifty per centum or more of the shares of that company directly or indirectly may, with the concurrence of the Minister assigned the subject of Finance and in consultation with the Auditor-General, appoint a qualified auditor or auditors to audit the accounts of such auditee entity. Where such appointment has been made by the Minister, the Auditor General may, in writing, inform such auditor or auditors that he proposes to utilise his or their services for the performance and discharge of the Auditor General's duties and functions in relation to such auditee entity and thereupon such auditor or auditors shall act under the direction and control of the Auditor-General."

question: Provisions for openness, timing, and structure:
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act, No. 3 of 2003:
The reports mentioned in Section 10. (1) and 13. (1) must be released to the public every year. 

Municipal Ordinance of 1947:
Section 218: "The Mayor shall, as soon as possible after the close of each financial year, prepare a detailed report of his administration during the previous year, with a statement showing the nature and amount of receipts and disbursements on account of the Municipal Fund during that year. Such report and statement shall be submitted to the Council, and with any resolutions that may be passed thereon by the Council, shall be submitted to the Minister within six weeks of the date when the same were first submitted to the Council."

Urban Councils Act of 1939:
Section 177 (1): "Every Urban Council shall cause to be prepared in writing, in the month of January in each year, or within such other period as the Council, with the sanction of the Commissioner may direct, a true account of all the moneys received and paid by virtue of this Ordinance during the year ending on the thirty-first day of December next preceding or such other period of twelve months as the Council, with the sanction of the Commissioner, may direct, and a statement of the assets and liabilities existing at the said date, and a copy or duplicate of such account and statement verified on oath before any Justice of the Peace by the Chairman of the Council, or such other officer of the Council as it may appoint for the purpose, and certified by one of the members to be correct, shall be deposited with the Council, and shall be open to the inspection of any householder resident within the town administered by the Council or any party interested."

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
The website PublicFinance.lk is a source of structured open data on government budget and spending information in Sri Lanka (1). Datasets on estimated (2) and actual (3) expenditure are available. While some data is provided to the public by the government of Sri Lanka (for example, see "Budget Estimates 2021" (4)), these tables are part of a report in PDF form, and therefore not structured open data. Hence, this question has been answered by analysing the open datasets provided by PublicFinance.lk. 

(1)PublicFinance.lk, "About Us." https://publicfinance.lk/en/about
(2) Breakdown of Government Expenditure by Category (Estimate), https://publicfinance.lk/en/data/detailedgovexpestimate
(3) Breakdown of Government Expenditure by Category (Actual), https://publicfinance.lk/en/data/govexpenditureactual
(4) Budget Estimates 2021 Volume III, Fiscal Year 2021. Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka. https://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/budget/2021/2021_aprovedBE_English_V_3.pdf
[Budget Estimates 2021 Volume III, Fiscal Year 2021. Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka](https://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/budget/2021/2021_aprovedBE_English_V_3.pdf)

question: Existence
Is this data available online in any form?

response: The website PublicFinance.lk (https://publicfinance.lk/en/about), which is run by the independent think tank VeritÃ© Research, contains these datasets. According to the disclaimer on the "About Us" page of the website, "The information contained on this platform has been compiled from government records, official publications, public records and information received by filing the Right to Information requests."

response: The dataset on estimated expenditure: "Breakdown of Government Expenditure by Category (Estimate)": https://publicfinance.lk/en/data/detailedgovexpestimate is the relevant dataset here. question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
The regulations did not directly require publishing data on public finances to the public. In the Official Information Act,it stated only each government agency must prepare the documents on budget relating to project.[1]

[1] Official Information Act. https://www.ocpb.go.th/download/pdf/act_eng_40.pdf

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
- The Official Information Act B.E. 2540 (1997)  requires government agencies to disclose their
information to the general public including the information on their concession contracts,
agreements of a monopolistic nature or joint venture agreements with private individuals
for the provision of public services.
- the Organic Act on Counter Corruption (No. 2) B.E. 2554 (2011) requires all government agencies to reveal reference prices of government procurement projects and how they are calculated via electronic
means.
- Annual Budget Expenditure Act

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
In Vietnam, regulations on publication of public finances are quite well-developed and more or less implemented. Key documents include Law on State budget 2015 and Decree 163/2016/NÄ-CP on guidance for implementation of Law on state budget. But publication of "open data" is still a new concept, which is addressed in Decree 47/2020/NÄ-CP.

The existing regulations provide quite concrete basis on publishing public finances (But mostly for gov budgets, gov spending; data on debt and borrowing are not clearly required to be published; even though it is mandatory to publish how much gov spends on paying debts or borrowing, or takes incomes from borrowing). Lists of types of public finance data, report formats, timeline for publication are all available. 
Here is the link to publication of public finances by Ministry of Finance: https://ckns.mof.gov.vn/SitePages/home.aspx

[Decree 163/2016/NÄ-CP on further instructions for Law on State Budget 2015](https://thuvienphapluat.vn/van-ban/Tai-chinh-nha-nuoc/Nghi-dinh-163-2016-ND-CP-huong-dan-Luat-ngan-sach-nha-nuoc-335331.aspx)

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response:
Yes. The existing regulations provide quite a concrete basis on publishing public finances (But mostly for gov budgets, gov spending; data on debt and borrowing are not clearly required to be published; even though it is mandatory to publish how much gov spends on paying debts or borrowing, or takes incomes from borrowing). Lists of types of public finance data, report formats, timeline for publication are all available. 
Here is the link to publication of public finances by Ministry of Finance: https://ckns.mof.gov.vn/SitePages/home.aspx
Publication must be:
â€¢ Available and accessible on online websites of government agencies (those that already have online websites. Compulsory at central and provincial levels. As for district or commune levels, online publication depends on availability of website infrastructure. 
â€¢ Promoted on mainstream media, local media channels, and listed at Municipal People's Committee headquarters for at least 30 days. This is mandatory for those which do not have online publication infrastructure. Those agencies that already have online publication are encouraged to implement these additional publication measures.
Covered contents: 
1) State budget estimates that have been submitted to the National Assembly and the People's
Councils; 
2) State budget estimates that have been approved by competent authorities; 
3) Reports on state budget enactment; 
4) State budget statements approved by the National Assembly and the People's Councils;
5) Estimates, enactment reports, statements of budgets 
Of the following covered entities: 
1) Budget estimate units (ex: Ministry of Finance, People's Committees, Finance departments, ...) 
2) Organizations funded by state budget, 
3) Fundamental construction programs/projects funded by state budget 
Key legal materials include:
Part 1, Article 15, Law on State budget 2015
Chapter VI, Decree 163/2016/NÄ-CP
Circular Decree 343/2016/TT-BTC: Guidance on publication on public finances for 4 state budget levels (central, provincil, district, communes)
Circular 61/2017/TT-BTC: Guidance on publication of public finances for 1) public estimate units and 2) organizations funded by state budget.
For the first time, it is made mandatory to publish reports on publication implementation rate. Specifically, budget publication compliance status from central to local public agencies will be collected and published. 
Circular 90/2018/TT-BTC, which provides clear technical requirements.
Budget publication on online websites of government agencies need to cover 4 categories: 
â€¢	Approved budgets
â€¢	Budget reports for 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, 12 months
â€¢	Final approved budget settlements
â€¢	Publication implementation rate
For each category, it is required to publish: 1) name of the report; 2) year; 3) name of report format according to Circulars' instructions; 4) number of the publication; 5) day of publication; and 6) links to digital version of the decision and the excel file of data
For the first time, XML format (machine readable) is made mandatory. Format of links to files is also fixed https://www.domain/ckns.xml

question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
response: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.

question: Provisions for data quality:
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
According to Circular 343/2016/TT-BTC:
At Central, Provincial, District, and Commune levels respectively:
Budget proposal: Within 5 working days since submission to National Assembly, People's Committees at Provincial, District, Commune levels
Budget enacted: within 30 days since enactment
Implementation report: within 15 days since end of quarter/ 6 months
Year-end reports: as soon as government submitted to National Assembly, People's Committees at Provincial, District, Commune levels

According to Circular 61/2017/TT-BTC for 1) public estimate units and 2) organizations funded by state budget:
Budget proposal: Within 15 days since submission to competent authorities
Quarterly and half-year reports: within 15 days since end of quarter, or 6th month
Yea-end Implementation reports to be submitted to competent authorities: within 5 working days since submission
Year-end final settlement reports: Within 15 days since enacted 

Moreover, due to requirement to publish implementation rates, according to Circular 61/2017/TT-BTC, collection and publication of required data should be made accurately and timely.

question: The framework requires a verification process.
2;Please briefly explain the verification process used.
response:
Article 16 of Law on State Budget 2015 allows supervision of public finances by the public through the Vietnamese father front. https://www.economica.vn/Content/files/LAW%20%26%20REG/83_2015_QH13%20Law%20on%20State%20budget.pdf 

Article 52 of Decree 163/2016/NÄ-CP further clarifies this point
Besides, Ministry of Finance and Department of Finance at all levels are responsible for monitoring information.

GDB team's question: Please describe the process described in the laws
IPS team's response: 
Law on State Budget 2015, Article 16. Supervision of state budget by the public
1. State budget shall be supervised by the public. Vietnamese Fatherland Front and other
agencies at various levels shall organize supervision of state budget by the public. Contents
of supervision of state budget by the public:
a) Adherence to regulations of law on management and use of state budget;
b) Enactment of annual state budget estimates;
c) Publishing of state budget as prescribed in Article 15 of this Law.
2. The government shall provide specific regulations on supervision of state budget by the
public

Decree 163/2016/NÄ-CP - Article 52 on public monitoring/ supervising over state budgets 
1. The Vietnamese Father front (VFF) at all levels lead the supervision process, cooperate with members of the VFF to organize and implement public supervision. 
2. VFF at all levels are responsible for receiving information, receiving request for supervision, making plan and implementing supervision activities 
3. Contents to be supervised are referred to in points a,b,c, Article 16.1, Law on state budget.
4. Supervision method:
a) research, assess government documentation related to state budgets
b) Establish supervision group
c) Joining relevant authorities in supervision activities 
Ä‘) Participating in activities of Public Investigation committee established at commune level and public Committee of investment supervision. 
5. Those who are under supervision shall have responsibilities to:
a) Provide information, documents to support supervision by VFF at all levels. 
b) Should make serious consideration, on-time response, proper explanation on comments/ recommendations from the public, VFF at all levels, and report to relevant authorities in case problems are out of their working scope.
c) Publish explanation, responses to comments/ recommendations from the public and VFF on supervision

question: Provisions for openness, timing, and structure:
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
2;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue.
response:
According to Circular 343/2016/TT-BTC:
At Central, Provincial, District, and Commune levels respectively:
Budget proposal: Within 5 working days since submission to National Assembly, People's Committees at Provincial, District, Commune levels
Budget enacted: within 30 days since enactment
Implementation report: within 15 days since end of quarter/ 6 months
Year-end reports: as soon as government submitted to National Assembly, People's Committees at Provincial, District, Commune levels

According to Circular 61/2017/TT-BTC for 1) public estimate units and 2) organizations funded by state budget:
Budget proposal: Within 15 days since submission to competent authorities
Quarterly and half-year reports: within 15 days since end of quarter, or 6th month
Yea-end Implementation reports to be submitted to competent authorities: within 5 working days since submission
Year-end final settlement reports: Within 15 days since enacted 
Moreover, due to requirement to publish implementation rates, according to Circular 61/2017/TT-BTC, collection and publication of required data should be made accurately and timely.

question: The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response:
Circular 90/2018/TT-BTC, which provides clear technical requirements. see amendments pursuant to Article 1(1)
Budget publication on online websites of government agencies need to cover 4 categories: 
â€¢	Approved budgets (not budget proposal)
â€¢	Budget reports for 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, 12 months
â€¢	Final approved budget settlements
â€¢	Publication implementation rate
For each category, it is required to publish: 1) name of the report; 2) year; 3) name of report format according to Circulars' instructions; 4) number of the publication; 5) day of publication; and 6) links to digital version of the decision and the excel file of data
For the first time, XML format (machine readable) is made mandatory. Format of links to files is also fixed https://www.domain/ckns.xml

question: To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
To what extent is government budget and spending information (budget execution) available as structured open data?
response:
In Vietnam, publication of government budget and spending information covers gov budgets and gov spending at aggregate level. Data on debt and borrowing are not clearly required to be published; even though it is mandatory to publish how much gov spends on paying debts or borrowing, or takes incomes from borrowing. There is no explicit restriction on re-use of the dataset. But there is no open license either. Only datasets on data.gov.vn are openly licensed. But they do not include public finances. In the Vietnamese context, it is mostly understood as data publication and data transparency rather than open data. 
This is the most comprehensive list of publications, by Ministry of Finance: https://ckns.mof.gov.vn/SitePages/home.aspx
In terms of detailed information as structured data in excel form, Da Nang has the most comprehensive list, including data on public debts, and line-by-line public expenditure. 
https://taichinh.danang.gov.vn/cktclist.do
Publication must be available and accessible on online websites of government agencies. 
Administrative classification: In all published datasets at both central and local levels, you can find united administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard. In Vietnam, it is also common to have classification of 63 municipalities, or municipalities at local levels, and geographical classification.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)

To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response: The public finance and budget, incomes, debts and expenditures are published clearly by the Ministry of Economy and Finances in its reports, which are public in the website of the Ministry. The data include also a summary of the financial reports, the fiscal indicators, the breakdown of the expenditures between levels of the government and each public authority. The information provided there include also a yearly detailed Public Expenditure And Financial Accountability (PEFA) Performance Assessment Report prepared by the World Bank.

question: Existence
Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
1,2;Please provide brief details.
response: The publication of the state incomes and expenditures are regulated by the Constitution of Albania. The article 157 of the Constitution in its point 4 regulates that central and local public authorities are obliged to make public all incomes and expenditures. The details of the budged lines, incomes and expenditures are provided by the yearly budget law, which is made public by the Ministry in charge for finances.

question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
response: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.

question: 1,2,3;Please provide a URL to the most relevant legislation, policy, or guidance.
Elements
Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields:
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
1;Please indicate which section of the framework refers to this issue and explain your 'Partially' response.
response:
The article 11 off the budget law regulates the incorporated budged tables which are provided as structured financial data. The matter is referred also by the law on financial management and control.
Even when there are tables provided, these tables only are stated in the law as the limits to which the budget should be carried, but it is not clear whether these are requirements for the publication of information.

response:
Basic law of Governance of Saudi Arabia n 90 of 1412 provides the legal text for public finance in the kingdom, Chapter seven Financial affairs (Article 72 to 78), in addition to the state revenue law n 68 of 1431.

The legal framework requires the creation of state budget and expenditures, but without any mention to structured data or a specific classification.

question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances? (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing.)
response:
This topic is supervised by Ministry of Finance as decreed by The Accounting Act (1). It stipulates that some 18,000 entities (municipalities and their organizations, other public entities) are required to provide the Ministry of Finance with their financial data regularly (monthly to yearly).

Other technical details are in the Decree 383/2009 (2).

This data is published by the Ministry on its portal Monitor - Complete overview of public finance (3).

1) The Accounting Act, https://www.zakonyprolidi.cz/cs/1991-563/

2) Decree 383/2009 on accounting records in technical form of selected accounting units and their transmission to the central accounting information system of the state and on requirements for technical and mixed forms of accounting records (technical decree on accounting records), https://www.zakonyprolidi.cz/cs/2009-383

3) Monitor - Complete overview of public finance, https://monitor.statnipokladna.cz/

4) Act on budgetary rules. https://www.zakonyprolidi.cz/cs/2000-218
